langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.l: The title of our Play, A Jovial Crew
May seem to promise Mirth: Which were a new,
And forced thing, in these sad and tragic days,
For you to find, or we express in Plays.
We wish you, then, would change that expectation,
Since Jovial Mirth is now grown out of fashion.
Or much not to expect: For, now it chances,
(Our Comic Writer finding that Romances
Of Lovers, through much travel and distress,
Till it be thought, no Power can redress
The afflicted Wanderers, though stout Chivalry
Lend all his aid for their delivery;
Till, lastly, some impossibility
Concludes all strife, and makes a Comedy);
Finding (he says) such stories bear the sway,
Near as he could, he has composed a Play,
Of Fortune-tellers, Damsels,and their Squires,
Exposed to strange Adventures, through the briers
Of Love and Fate.But why need I forestall
What shall so soon be obvious to you all:
But with the dullness may make no man sleep,
Nor sadness of it any Woman weep.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: IT has indeed, Friend, much afflicted me.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: And very justly, let me tell you, Sir,
That could so impiously be curious
You tempt a judgment on you; to give ear,
And Faith too (by your leave) to Fortune-tellers,
Wizards and Gypsies!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I have since been frighted
With it in a thousand dreams.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I would be drunk
A thousand times to bed, rather than dream
Of any of their Riddlemy Riddlemies,
If they prove happy so: If not, let it go;
You will never find their meaning till the event,
If you suppose there was, at all, a meaning,
As the equivocating Devil had, when he
Cozened the Monk, to let him live soul-free,
Till he should find him sleeping between sheets:
The wary Monk, adjuring all such lodging,
At last, by over-watching in his study,
The foul Fiend took him napping with his nose
Betwixt the sheet-leaves of his conjuring Book.
There was the whim, or double meaning of it.
But these fond Fortune-tellers, that know nothing,
Aim to be thought more cunning than their Master,
The foresaid Devil, though truly not so hurtful:
Yet, trust them, Hang them, Wizards! old blind Buzzards!
For once they hit, they miss a thousand times;
And most times give quite contrary, bad for good,
And best for worst. One told a Gentleman
His son should be a man-killer, and hanged for it;
Who, after proved a great and rich Physician,
And with great Fame in the University
Hanged up in Picture for a grave example.
There was the whim of that. Quite contrary!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: And that was happy, would mine could so deceive my fears,

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: They may: but trust not to it. Another Schemist
Found, that a squint-eyed boy should prove a notable
Pick-purse, and afterwards a most strong thief;
When he grew up to be a cunning Lawyer,
And at last died a Judge. Quite contrary!
How many have been marked out by these Wizards
For fools, that after have been pricked for Sheriffs?
Was not a Shepherd-boy foretold to be
A Drunkard, and to get his living from
Bawds, Whores, Thieves, Quarrellers, and the like?
And did he not become a Suburb Justice?
And live in Wine and Worship by the Fees
Racked out of such Delinquents? There is the whim of it.
Now I come to you: Your Figure-flinger finds,
That both your Daughters, notwithstanding all
Your great Possessions, which they are Co-heirs of,
Shall yet be Beggars. May it not be meant,
(If, as I said, there be a meaning in it)
They may prove Courtiers, or great Courtier's wives,
And so be Beggars in Law? If not that
sp.p:
the whim of it think you? you shall think no worse
of it.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Would I had your merry heart.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I mean the like.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I would you had; and I
Such an Estate as yours. Four thousand yearly,
With such a heart as mine, would defy Fortune,
And all her babbling Sooth-sayers. I would as soon
Distrust in Providence, as lend a fear
To such a Destiny, for a Child of mine,
While there be Sack and Songs in Town or Country.
Think like a man of conscience (now I am serious)
What justice can there be for such a curse
To fall upon your Heirs? Do you not live
Free, out of Law, or grieving any man?
Are you not the only rich man lives un-envied?
Have you not all the praises of the Rich,
And prayers of the Poor? Did ever any
Servant, or Hireling, Neighbour, Kindred curse you,
Or wish one minute shortened of your life?
Have you one grudging Tenant? will they not all
Fight for you? Do they not teach their Children,
And make them too, pray for you morn and evening,
And in their Graces too, as duly as
For King and Realm? The innocent things would think
They ought not eat else.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: It is their goodness.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: It is your merit. Your great love and bounty
Procures from Heaven those inspirations in them.
Whose Rent did ever you exact? whose have
You not remitted, when by casualties
Of fire, of floods, of common dearth, or sickness,
Poor men were brought behind hand? Nay, whose losses.
Have you not piously repaired?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Enough.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: What Hariots have you taken from forlorn Widows?
What Acre of your thousands have you racked?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Good Friend, no more.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: These are enough, indeed,
To fill your ears with joyful acclamations
Wherever you pass: Heaven bless our Landlord Oldrent;
Our Master Oldrent; our good Patron Oldrent.
Cannot these sounds conjure that evil spirit
Of fear out of you, that your Children shall
Live to be Beggars? Shall Squire Oldrent's Daughters
Wear old rents in their Garments? there is a whim too)
Because a Fortune-teller told you so?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Come, I will strive to think no more on it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Will you ride forth for air then, and be merry?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Your counsel and example may instruct me.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Sack must be had in sundry places too.
For Songs I am provided.

div2.stage:
Enter Springlove with Books and Papers,
he layes them on the Table.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Yet here comes one brings me a second fear,
Who has my care the next unto my children.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Your Steward, Sir, it seems has business with you.
I wish you would have none.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I will soon dispatch it:
And then be for our journey instantly.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I will wait your coming down, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: But why, Springlove,
Is now this expedition?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Sir, It is duty.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Not common among Stewards, I confess,
To urge in their Accounts before the day
Their Lords have limited. Some that are grown
To hoary hairs and Knighthoods, are not found
Guilty of such an importunity.
It is yet but thirty days, when I give forty
After the half-year day, our Lady last.
Could I suspect my Trust were lost in thee;
Or doubt thy youth had not ability
To carry out the weight of such a charge,
I, then, should call on thee.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Sir, your indulgence,
I hope, shall never corrupt me. Nevertheless,
The testimony of a fair discharge
From time to time, will be encouragement

div2.stage:
Springlove turns over the several Books to
his Master.

sp.l: To virtue in me. You may then be pleased
To take here a Survey of all your Rents
Received, and all such other payments, as
Came to my hands since my last Audit, for
Cattle, Wool, Corn, all Fruits of Husbandry.
Then, my Receipts on Bonds, and some new Leases,
With some old debts, and almost desperate ones,
As well from Country Cavaliers, as Courtiers.
Then, here Sir, are my several disbursements,
In all particulars for yourself and Daughters,
In charge of House-keeping, Buildings and Repairs;
Journeys, Apparel, Coaches, Gifts, and all
Expenses for your personal necessaries.
Here, Servants wages, Liveries, and Cures.
Here for supplies of Horses, Hawks and Hounds.
And lastly, not the least to be remembered,
Your large Benevolences to the Poor.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Thy charity there goes hand in hand with mine.
And, Springlove, I commend it in thee, that
So young in years art grown so ripe in goodness.
May their Heaven-piercing Prayers bring on thee
Equal rewards with me.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Now here, Sir, is
The balance of the several Accounts,
Which shows you what remains in Cash: which added
Unto your former Bank, makes up in all --

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Twelve thousand and odd pounds.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Here are the keys
Of all. The Chests are safe in your own Closet.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Why in my Closet? is not yours as safe?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: O, Sir, you know my suit.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Your suit? what suit?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Touching the time of year.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: It is well-nigh May.
Why what of that, good Springlove?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: O, Sir, you hear I am called.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Fie Springlove, fie.
I hoped thou hadst adjured that uncouth practice.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You thought I had forsaken Nature then.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Is that disease of Nature still in thee
So virulent? and, notwithstanding all
My favours, in my gifts, my cares, and counsels,
Which to a soul ingrateful might be boasted:
Have I first bred thee, and then preferred thee (from
I will not say how wretched a beginning)
To be a Master over all my Servants;
Planted thee in my bosom; and canst thou
There, 'slight me for the whistling of a Bird?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Your reason, Sir, informs you, that is no cause.
But it is the season of the year that calls me.
What moves her Noats, provokes my disposition
By a more absolute power of Nature, than
Philosophy can render an accompt for.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I find there is no expelling it; but still
It will return. I have tried all the means
(As I may safely think) in human wisdom,
And did (as near as reason could) assure me,
That thy last years restraint had stopped forever,
That running sore on thee, that gadding humour:
When, only for that cause, I laid the weight
Of mine Estate in Stewardship upon thee;
Which kept thee in that year, after so many
Summer vagaries thou hadst made before.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You kept a Swallow in a Cage that while.
I cannot, Sir, endure another Summer
In that restraint, with life: it was then my torment,
But now, my death. Yet, Sir, my life is yours:
Who are my Patron; freely may you take it.
Yet pardon, Sir, my frailty, that do beg
A small continuance of it on my knees.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Can there no means be found to preserve life
In thee, but wandering, like a Vagabond?
Does not the Sun as comfortably shine
Upon my Gardens, as the opener Fields?
Or on my Fields, as others far remote?
Are not my Walks and Greens as delectable
As the High-ways and Commons? Are the shades
Of Sycamore and Bowers of Eglantine
Less pleasing than of Bramble, or thorne hedges?
Or of my Groves and Thickets, than wild Woods?
Are not my Fountain waters fresher than
The troubled streams, where every Beast does drink?
Do not the Birds sing here as sweet and lively,
As any other where? is not thy bed more soft,
And rest more safe, than in a Field or Barn?
Is a full Table, which is called thine own,
Less curious or wholesome, than the scraps
From others trenchers, twice or thrice translated?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Yea, in the winter season, when the fire
Is sweeter than the air.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: What air is wanting?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: O Sir, you have heard of Pilgrimages; and
The voluntary travels of good men.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: For Penance; or to holy ends? but bring
Not those into comparison, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I do not, Sir. But pardon me, to think
Their sufferings are much sweetened by delights,
Such as we find, by shifting place and air.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Are there delights in beggary? Or, if to take
Diversity of Air be such a solace,
Travel the Kingdom over: And if this
Yield not variety enough, try further:
Provided your deportment be gentile.
Take Horse, and Man, and Money: you have all,
Or I will allow enough.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: O how am I confounded!
Dear Sir, retort me naked, to the world,
Rather than lay those burdens on me, which
Will stifle me. I must abroad or perish.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I will no longer strive to wash this Moor:
Nor breath more minutes so unthriftily,
In civil argument, against rude wind,
But rather practise to withdraw my love
And tender care (if it be possible)
From that unfruitful breast; incapable
Of wholesome counsel.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Have I your leave, Sir?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I leave you to dispute it with yourself.
I have no voice to bid you go, or stay:
My love shall give thy will pre-eminence;
And leave the effect to Time and Providence --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I am confounded in my obligation
To this good man: His virtue is my punishment,
When it is not in my Nature to return
Obedience to his Merits. I could wish
Such an Ingratitude were Death by the law,
And put in present execution on me,
You rid me of my sharper suffering.
Nor but by death, can this predominant sway
Of nature be extinguished in me. I
Have fought with my Affections, by the assistance
Of all the strength of Art and Discipline
(All which I owe him for in education too)
To conquer and establish my observance
(As in all other rules) to him in this,
This inborn strong desire of liberty
In that free course, which he detects as shameful,
And I approve my earths felicity:
But find the war is endless, and must fly.
What must I lose then? A good Master's love.
What loss feels he that wants not what he loses?
They will say I lose all Reputation.
What is that, to live where no such thing is known?
My duty to a Master will be questioned.
Where duty is exacted it is none:
And among Beggars, each man is his own.
sp.stage:
Enter Randal and three or four servants with a great
Kettle, and black Jacks, and a Bakers Basket, all empty, exeunt with all, manet Randal.
sp.p: Now fellows, what news from whence you came?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
The old wonted news, Sir, from your Guesthouse,
the old Barn. We have unloaded the Bread-basket,
the Beef-Kettle, and the Beer-Bumbards there,
amongst your Guests: the Beggars. And they have all
prayed for you and our Master, as their manner is,
from the teeth outward, marry from the teeth inwards
it is enough to swallow your Alms; from
whence I think their Prayers seldom come.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Thou shouldst not think uncharitably.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Thought is free, Master Steward, if it please
you. But your Charity is nevertheless notorious, I
must needs say.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Meritorious thou meantest to say.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Surely Sir, no; it is out of our Curate's Book.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: But I aspire no merits, nor popular thanks,
It is well if I do well in it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
It might be better though (if old Randal,
whom you allow to talk, might counsel) to help to
breed up poor men's children, or decayed labourers,
past their work, or travel; or towards the setting up
of poor young married couples; than to bestow an
hundred pound a year (at least you do that, if not all
you get) besides our Masters bounty, to maintain in
begging such wanderers as these, that never are out
of their way; that cannot give account from whence
they came, or whither they would; nor of any beginning
they ever had, or any end they seek, but
still to stroll and beg till their bellies be full, and
then sleep till they be hungry.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Thou art ever repining at those poor people!
they take nothing from thee but thy pains: and that
I pay thee for too. Why shouldst thou grudge?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Am I not bitten to it every day, by the six-footed
blood-hounds that they leave in their Litter,
when I throw out the old, to lay fresh straw for the
new comers at night. That is one part of my office.
And you are sure that though your hospitality be but
for a night and a morning for one Rabble, to have
a new supply every evening. They take nothing from
me indeed, they give too much.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Thou art old, Randall still ever grumbling,
but still officious for them.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Yes: hang them, they know I love them well
enough, I have had merry hours with some of them.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What sayst thou Randall?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
They are indeed my pastime. I left the merry
Griggs (as their provender has pricked them) in such a
Hoigh yonder! such a frolic! you will hear anon, as
you walk nearer them.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Well honest Randal. Thus it is. I am for a
journey. I know not how long will be my absence.
But I will presently take order with the Cook,
Pantler and Butler, for my wonted allowance to the
Poor; And I will leave money with thee to manage
the affair till my return.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Then up rise Randal, Bailey of the Beggars.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
And if our Master shall be displeased (although
the charge be mine) at the openness of the
Entertainment, thou shalt then give it proportionably
in money, and let them walk farther.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Pseugh! that will never do it, never do them
good: It is the Seat, the Habitation, the Rendezvous,
that cheers their hearts. Money would clog
their consciences. Nor must I lose the music of them
in their lodging.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
We will agree upon it anon. Go now about
your business.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I go. Bailey? nay Steward and Chamberlain
of the Rogues and Beggars.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I cannot think but with a trembling fear
On this adventure, in a scruple, which
I have not weighed with all my other doubts.
I shall, in my departure, rob my Master.
Of what? of a true Servant; other theft
I have committed none. And that may be supplied,
And better too, by some more constant to him.
But I may injure many in his Trust,
Which now he cannot be but sparing of.
I rob him too; of the content and hopes
He had in me, whom he had built and raised
Unto that growth in his affection,
That I became a gladness in his eye,
And now must be a grief or a vexation
Unto his noble heart. But hark! Aye there is
The Harmony that drowns all doubts and fears.
A little nearer --
FRom hunger and cold who lives more free,
Or who more richly clad than we?
Our bellies are full; our flesh is warm;
And, against pride, our rags are a charm:
Enough is our Feast, and for tomorrow
Let rich men care: we feel no sorrow.
No sorrow, no sorrow, no sorrow, no sorrow.
Let rich men care, we feel no sorrow.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p:
The Emperor hears no such Music; nor
feels content like this!

sp.l: Each City, each Town, and every Village,
Affords us either an Alms or Pillage.
And if the weather be cold and raw
Then, in a Barn we tumble in straw.
If warm and fair, by yea-cock and nay-cock.
The Fields will afford us a Hedge or a Hay-cock.
A Hay-cock, a Hay-cock, a Hay-cock, a Hay-cock,
The Fields will afford us a Hedge or a Hay-cock.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Most ravishing delight! But, in all this
only one sense is pleased: mine ear is feasted.
Mine eye too must be satisfied with my joys.
The hoarding Usurer cannot have more
Thirsty desire to see his golden store,
When he unlocks his Treasury, than I
The equipage in which my Beggars lie.

div2.stage:
He opens the Scene; the Beggars are discovered in
their postures; then they issue forth; and last,
the Patrico.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
Our Master, our Master! our sweet and comfortable
Master.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: How cheer my hearts?

sp.speaker: 1. Beg.
sp.l: Most crouse, most caperingly.
Shall we dance, shall we sing, to welcome our King?
Strike up Piper a merry merry dance
That we on our stampers may foot it and prance,
To make his heart merry as he has made ours;
As lustick and frolic as Lords in their Bowers.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Exceeding well performed.

sp.speaker: 1. Beg.
sp.p:
It is well if it like you, Master. But we
have not that rag among us, that we will not dance
off, to do you service; we being all and only your
servants, most noble Sir. Command us therefore
and employ us, we beseech you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Thou speakest most courtly.

sp.speaker: 2. Beg.
sp.p:
Sir, he can speak, and could have writ as
well. He is a decayed Poet, newly fallen in among
us; and begs as well as the best of us. He learnt it
pretty well in his own profession before; and can
the better practise it in ours now.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Thou art a wit too, it seems.

sp.speaker: 3. Beg.
sp.p:
He should have wit and knavery too, Sir:
For he was an Attorney, till he was pitched over the
Bar. And, from that fall, he was taken up a Knight
of the Post; and so he continued, till he was degraded
at the whipping-post; and from thence he ran
resolutely into this course. His cunning in the Law,
and the others labour with the Muses are dedicate to
your service; and for myself, I will fight for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Thou art a brave fellow, and speakest like a
Commander. Hast thou born Arms?

sp.speaker: 4. Beg.
sp.p:
Sir, he has born the name of a Netherlands
Soldier, till he ran away from his Colours, and was
taken lame with lying in the Fields by a Sciatica: I
mean, Sir, the strapado. After which, by a second retreat,
indeed running away, he scrambled into his
Country, and so scaped the Gallows; and then snapped
up his living in the City by his wit in cheating, pimping,
and such like Arts, till the Cart and the Pillory
showed him too publicly to the world. And so,
begging being the last refuge, he entered into our society.
And now lives honestly, I must needs say, as
the best of us.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Thou speakest good language too.

sp.speaker: 1. Beg.
sp.p:
He was a Courtier born, Sir, and begs on
pleasure I assure you, refusing great and constant
means from able friends to make him a staid man.
Yet (the want of a leg notwithstanding) he must travel
in this kind against all common reason, by the
special policy of Providence.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: As how I prithee?

sp.speaker: 1. Beg.
sp.l: His Father, Sir, was a Courtier; a great Court Beggar I assure you;
I made these Verses of Him and his Son here.
A Courtier begged by Covetise, not Need,
From Others that, which made them beg indeed.
He begged, till wealth had laden him with cares
To keep for his children and their children shares:
While the oppressed, that lost that great Estate
Sent Curses after it unto their Fate.
The Father dies (the world says) very rich;
The Son, being gotten while (it seems) the itch
Of begging was upon the Courtly Sire,
Or bound by Fate, will to no wealth aspire,
Though offered him in Money, Clothes or Meat,
More than he begs, or instantly must eat.
Is not he heavenly blessed, that hates Earth's Treasure
And begs, with What is a Gentleman but his pleasure?
Or say it be upon the Heir a curse;
What is that to him? The Beggar is never the worse.
For of the general store that Heaven has sent
He values not a penny till it be spent.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Scribble, a Scribble!

sp.speaker: 2. Beg.
sp.p:
What City or Court Poet could say more
than our hedge Muse-monger here?

sp.speaker: 2 Beg.
sp.p: What say, Sir, to our Poet Scribble here?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I like his vain exceeding well; and the whole
Consort of you.

sp.speaker: 2 Beg.
sp.p:
Consort, Sir. We have Musicians too among
us: true merry Beggars indeed, that being
within the reach of the Lash for singing libellous
Songs at London, were fain to fly into our covey,
and here they sing all our Poet's Ditties. They can
sing anything most tunably, Sir, but Psalms. What
they may do hereafter under a triple Tree, is much
expected. But they live very civilly and gentily among
us.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
But what is he there? that solemn old fellow,
that neither speaks of himself, nor anybody
for him.

sp.speaker: 2 Beg.
sp.p:
O Sir, the rarest man of all. He is a Prophet.
See how he holds up his prognosticating nose,
He is divining now.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How? a Prophet?

sp.speaker: 2 Beg.
sp.p:
Yes Sir, a cunning man and a Fortune-teller:
it is thought he was a great Clerk before his
decay, but he is very close, will not tell his beginning,
nor the fortune he himself is fallen from: But
he serves us for a Clergy-man still, and marries us, if
need be, after a new way of his own.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How long have you had his company?

sp.speaker: 2 Beg.
sp.p:
But lately come amongst us, but a very
ancient Stroll all the Land over, and has travelled
with Gypsies, and is a Patrico. Shall he read your Fortune
Sir?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: If it please him.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Lend me your hand, Sir.
sp.l: By this Palm I understand,
Thou art born to wealth and Land,
And after many a bitter gust,
Shalt build with thy great Grandsires dust.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Where shall I find it? but come, I will not
trouble my head with the search.

sp.speaker: 2 Beg.
sp.p:
What say, Sir, to our Crew? are we not
well congregated?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You are A Jovial Crew; the only people
Whose happiness I admire.

sp.speaker: 3 Beg.
sp.p:
Will you make us happy in serving you?
have you any Enemies? shall we fight under you?
will you be our Captain?
Nay, our King.
Command us something, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Where is the next Rendezvous?

sp.l: Neither in Village nor in Town:
But three mile off at Mapledown.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: At evening there I will visit you.
Come, come; away: the Spring
(By every Bird that can but sing,
Or chirp a note) doth now invite
Us forth, to taste of his delight.
In Field, in Grove, on Hill, in Dale;
But above all the Nightingale:
Who in her sweetness strives to out-do
The loudness of the hoarse Cuckoo.
Cuckoo cries he, Jug Jug Jug sings she,
From bush to bush, from tree to tree,
Why in one place then tarry we?
Come away; why do we stay?
We have no debt or rent to pay.
No bargains or accounts to make;
Nor Land or Lease to let or take:
Or If we had; should that remove us,
When all the world is our own before us,
And where we pass, and make resort,
It is our Kingdom and our Court.
Cuckoo cries he, etc.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: So, now away.
They dream of happiness that live in State,
But they enjoy it that obey their Fate.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I Am overcome with admiration, at the felicity
they take!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
Beggars! They are the only people, can boast
the benefit of a free state, in the full enjoyment of Liberty,
Mirth and Ease; having all things in common
and nothing wanting of Natures whole provision
within the reach of their desires. Who would have
lost this sight of their Revels?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
How think you Ladies? Are they not the only
happy in a Nation?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Happier than we I am sure, that are pent up
and tied by the nose to the continual stream of hot
Hospitality, here in our Father's house, when they
have the Air at pleasure in all variety.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
And though I know we have merrier Spirits
than they, yet to live thus confined, stifles us.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
Why Ladies, you have liberty enough; or
may take what you please.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Yes in our Father's Rule and Government,
or by his allowance. What is that to absolute freedom;
such as the very Beggars have; to feast and
revel here today, and yonder tomorrow; next day
where they please; and so on still, the whole Country
or Kingdom over? there is Liberty! the birds of
the air can take no more.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
And then at home here, or wheresoever he
comes, our Father is so pensive, (what muddy spirit
soever possesses him, would I could conjure it out)
that he makes us even sick of his sadness, that were
wont to see my Chossips cock today; mold Cocklebread;
dance clutterdepouch; and iannykin booby; bind barrels;
or do anything before him, and he would
laugh at us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Now he never looks upon us, but with a sigh,
or tears in his eyes, though we simper never so sanctifiedly.
What tales have been told him of us, or what
he suspects I know not; God forgive him, I do; but
I am weary of his house.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Does he think us Whores trow, because sometimes
we talk as lightly as great Ladies. I can swear
safely for the virginity of one of us, so far as Word and
Deed goes; marry Thought is free.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Which is that one of us I pray? yourself
or me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Good sister Meriel, Charity begins at home.
But I will swear I think as charitably of thee: And not
only because thou art a year younger neither.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
I am beholden to you. But for my Father, I
would I knew his grief and how to cure him, or that
we were where we could not see it. It spoils our
mirth, and that has been better than his Meat to us.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Will you hear our motion Ladies?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Psew, you would marry us presently out of
his way, because he has given you a foolish kind of
promise: But we will see him in a better humour first,
and as apt to laugh as we to lie down, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
It is like that course will cure him, would
you embrace it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
We will have him cured first, I tell you: And
you shall wait that season, and our leisure.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
I will rather hazard my being one of the Devil's
Ape-leaders, than to marry while he is melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Or I to stay in his house; to give entertainment
to this Knight, or the other Coxcomb, that comes
to cheer him up with eating of his cheer: when we
must fetch them sweetmeats, and they must tell us,
Ladies, your lips are sweeter, and then fall into
Courtship, one in a set speech taken out of old Britains
Works, another with Verses out of the Academy
of Complements, or some or other of the new Poetical
Pamphleteers, ambitious only to spoil Paper,
and publish their names in print. And then to
be kissed, and sometimes slavered -- faugh.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
It is not to be endured. We must out of the
House. We cannot live but by laughing, and that
aloud, and nobody sad within hearing.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
We are for any adventure with you, Ladies.
Shall we project a journey for you? your Father has
trusted you, and will think you safe in our company;
and we would fain be abroad upon some progress
with you. Shall we make a fling to London, and
see how the Spring appears there in the Spring-Garden;
and in Hide-park, to see the Races, Horse and
Foot; to hear the jockeys crack; and see the Adamites
run naked afore the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
We have seen all already there, as well as
they, last year.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But there have been new Plays since.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No: no: we are not for London.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
What think you of a Journey to the Bath
then?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Worse than the other way. I love not to carry
my Health where others drop their Diseases. There is
no sport in that.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Will you up to the hill top of sports, then,
and Merriments, Dovors Olimpicks or the Cotswold
Games.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
No, that will be too public for our Recreation.
We would have it more within ourselves.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
Think of some course yourselves then. We
are for you upon any way, as far as Horse and Money
can carry us.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Aye, and if those means fail us, as far as our
legs can bear, or our hands can help us.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And we will put you to it. Come aside Meriel --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Some jeer, perhaps to put upon us.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
What think you of a Pilgrimage to Saint Winifrides
Well?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Or a Journey to the wise woman at Nantwich,
to ask if we be fit husbands for them?

sp.speaker: Hil.
Ra. Me.
sp.p: Ha, ha ha --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What is the conceit I marvel.

sp.speaker: Ra. Me.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Some merry one it seems.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
And then, sirrah Meriel -- Hark again -- ha
ha ha --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: How they are taken with it!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ha ha ha -- Hark again Rachel.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Some wonderful Nothing sure. They will
laugh as much to see a swallow fly with a white feather
imped in her tail.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: They were born laughing I think.

sp.speaker: Ra. Me.
sp.p: Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
If it be not some trick upon us, which they will
discover in some monstrous shape, they cozen me.
Now Ladies, is your Project ripe? possess us with
the knowledge of it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
It is more precious, than to be imparted upon
a 'slight demand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
Pray let us hear it. You know we are your
trusty servants.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
And have kept all your councils ever since
we have been Infant Playfellows.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Yes, you have played at all kinds of small game
with us; but this is to the purpose. Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It seems so by your laughing.

sp.speaker: Ra.
Vin.
sp.p:
You know how, and what we have vowed:
to wait upon you any way, any how, and any whither.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And you will stand to it?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Aye, and go to it with you, wherever it be.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Pray tell them, sister Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Why Gentlemen -- ha ha -- Thus it is -- Tell
it you Meriel.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: O, is that all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You are the elder. Pray tell it you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You are the younger. I command you tell it.
Come, out with it
They long to have it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
In troth you must tell it, sister, I cannot.
Pray begin.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Then Gentlemen stand your ground.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Some terrible business sure!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
You seemed even now to admire the felicity of
Beggars.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And have engaged yourselves to join with
us in any course.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Will you now with us, and for our sakes turn
Beggars?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
It is our Resolution, and our Injunction on
you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But for a Time, and short Progress.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And for a spring-trick of youth, now, in
the season.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Beggars! What Rogues are these?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: A simple trial of our Loves and service!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Are you resolved upon it? If not God be-with-ye.
We are resolved to take our course.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Let yours be to keep council.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Stay, stay. Beggars! Are we not so already?
Do we not beg your loves, and your enjoyings?
Do we not beg to be received your servants?
To kiss your hands, or (if you will vouchsafe)
Your lips; or your embraces?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: We now beg,
That we may fetch the Rings and Priest to marry us.
Wherein are we no Beggars?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: That will not serve. Your time is not come for that yet.
You shall beg Victuals first.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
O, I conceive your begging progress is to
ramble out this summer among your Father's Tenants;
and it is in request among Gentlemen's Daughters
to devour their Cheese-cakes, Apple-pies, Cream and
Custards, Flapjacks; and Pan-puddings.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Not so, not so,

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why so we may be a kind of civil Beggars.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I mean stark, errant, downright Beggars, I,
Without equivocation; Statute Beggars .

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Couchant and Passant, Guardant, Rampant
Beggars.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Current and vagrant --

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Stockant, whippant Beggars!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Must you and we be such? would you so
have it?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Such as we saw so merry; and you concluded
Were the only happy People in a Nation.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The only Freemen of a Common-wealth;
Free above Scot-free; that observe no Law,
Obey no Governor, use no Religion,
But what they draw from their own ancient custom,
Or constitute themselves, yet are no Rebels.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Such as of all men's Meat and all men's Money
Take a free part; and, wheresoever they travel.
Have all things gratis to their hands provided.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Course fare most times.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Their stomach makes it good;
And feasts on that, which others scorn for Food.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Antidote, Content, is only theirs.
And, unto that, such full delights are known,
That they conceive the kingdom is their own.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Before Heaven I think they are in earnest: for
they were always mad.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
And we were madder than they, if we should
lose them.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
It is but a mad trick of youth (as they say)
for the Spring, or a short progress: and mirth may be
made out of it; knew we how to carry it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray Gentlemen be sudden.
Hark, you hear the Cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We are most resolutely for you in your course.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: But the vexation is how to set it on foot.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
We have projected it. Now if you be perfect
and constant Lovers and friends, search you the
means. We have puzzled them.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I am glad of it. Let them pump.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Troth a small stock will serve to set up withal.
This Doublet sold off of my back, might serve
to furnish a Camp Royal of us.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
But how to enter or arrange ourselves into
the Crew will be the difficulty. If we light raw and
tame amongst them (like Cage-Birds among a flight
of wild ones) we shall never pick up a Living, but
have our brains pecked out.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: We want instruction dearly.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
O here comes Springlove. His great Benefactorship
among the Beggars might prefer us with Authority
into a ragged Regiment presently. Shall I
put it to him.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Take heed what you do. His greatness with
my Father will betray us.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I will cut his throat then. My noble Springlove,
the great Commander of the Maunders, and
King of Canters, we saw the gratitude of your loyal
Subjects, in the large Tributary content they gave
you in their Revels.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Did you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We have seen all with great delight and admiration.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I have seen you too, kind Gentlemen and
Ladies; and over-heard you in your quaint design,
to new create yourselves out of the worldly blessings,
and spiritual graces Heaven has bestowed upon
you, to be partakers and Co-actors too, in those vile
courses, which you call delights, taken by those despicable
and abhorred Creatures.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Thou art a Despiser, nay a Blasphemer
Against the Maker of those happy Creatures.
Who, of all human, have priority
In their content. In which they are so blessed
That they enjoy most in possessing least.
Who made them such, dost think? or why so happy?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
He grows zealous in the Cause: sure he will beg
indeed.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Art thou an Hypocrite, then, all this while?
only pretending Charity; or using it
To get a Name and Praise unto thyself;
And not to cherish and increase those Creatures,
In their most happy way of living? Or
Dost thou bestow thine Alms with a foul purpose
To stint their Begging, and with loss to buy
And slave those free souls from their liberty?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: They are more zealous in the Cause than we.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: But are you, Ladies, at defiance too
With Reputation, and the Dignity
Due to your Father's House and You?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hold thy peace, good Springlove,
And, though you seem to dislike this course, and reprove us for it,
Do not betray us in it: your throat is in question.
I tell you for good will good Springlove.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have us do?
Thou talkest of the House.
It is a base melancholy House.
Our Father's sadness banishes us out of it.
sp.p:
And, for the delight thou takest in Beggars and their
brawls, thou canst not but think they live a better
life abroad, than we do in this House.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I have founded your Faith: And I am glad I
find you all right. And for your Father's sadness,
I will tell you the cause of it. I over-heard it but this
day in his private Discourse with his merry Mate
Master Hearty. He has been told by some Wizard that
you both were born to be Beggars.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How. How!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
For which he is so tormented in mind, that
he cannot sleep in peace, nor look upon you but
with hearts grief.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: This is most strange.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Let him be grieved then, till we are Beggars,
We have just reason to become so now:
And, what we thought on but in jest before,
We will do in earnest now.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: O, I applaud this resolution in you;
Would have persuaded it; will be your Servant in it.
For, look ye, Ladies:
sp.p:
The Sentence of your Fortune does not say, that you
shall beg for need; hungry or cold necessity. If therefore
you expose yourselves on pleasure into it, you
shall absolve your destiny nevertheless; and cure
your Father's grief. I am overjoyed to think on it,
and will assist you faithfully.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Springlove! a Springlove!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I am prepared already for the adventure.
And will with all convenience furnish,
And set you forth; give you your Dimensions,
Rules and Directions: I will be your Guide,
Your Guard, your Convoy, your Authority.
You do not know my Power; my Command
In the Beggars Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: But how? But how, good Springlove?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I will confess all. In my Minority
My Master took me up a naked Beggar;
Bred me at School; then took me to his Service;
(You know in what good fashion) and you may
Collect to memory for seven late Summers,
Either by leave, pretending Friends to see
At far remote parts of the Land, or else,
By stealth, I would absent myself from service,
To follow my own Pleasure, which was Begging,
Led to it by Nature. My indulgent Master
(Yet ignorant of my course) on my submission
When Cold and Hunger forced me back at Winter,
Received me still again. Till, two years since,
He being drawn by journey towards the North,
Where I then quartered with a ragged Crew;
On the high way, not dreaming of him there,
I did accost him, with a Good your Worship
The Gift one small penny to a Cripple;
(For here I was with him) and the good Lord
To bless you, and restore it you in Heaven.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: My head was dirty clouted, and this leg
Swaddled with Rags, the other naked, and
My body clad, like his upon the Gibbet.
Yet, He, with searching eyes, through all my Rags
And counterfeit Postures, made discovery
Of his Man Springlove; chid me into tears;
And a confession of my forespent life.
At last, upon condition, that vagary
Should be the last, he gave me leave to run
That Summer out. In Autumn home came I
In my home Clothes again and former Duty.
My Master not alone conserved my Counsel;
But lays more weighty Trust and Charge upon me;
Such was his love to keep me a home-Man,
That he conferred his Stewards place upon me,
Which clogged me, the last year, from those Delights,
I would not lose again to be his Lord.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Springlove, a Springlove.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Pursue the course you are on then, as cheerful
As the inviting Season smiles upon you.
Think how you are necessitated to it,
To quit your Father's sadness, and his fears
Touching your Fortune. Till you have been Beggars
The Sword hangs over him. You cannot think
Upon an Act of greater Piety
Unto your Father, than to expose yourselves
Brave Volunteers, unpressed by common need
Into this meritorious Warfare; whence
(After a few days, or short season spent)
You bring him a perpetual Peace and Joy
By expiating the Prophecy that torments him.
It were worth your Time in painful, woeful steps,
With your lives hazard in a Pilgrimage,
So to redeem a Father. But you will find
A Progress of such Pleasure (as I will govern it)
That the most happy Courts could never boast
In all their Tramplings on the Countries cost;
Whose envy we shall draw, when they shall read
We out-beg them, and for as little Need.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Springlove! a Springlove!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Follow me, Gallants, then, as cheerfully
As -- (hark!) we are summoned forth.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We follow thee.

div2.stage: Enter Randal. A Purse in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Well, go thy ways. If ever any just or charitable
Steward was commended, sure thou shalt be
at the last Quarter-day. Here is five and twenty
pounds for this Quarters Beggar-charge. And (if he
return not by the end of this Quarter) here is order
to a Friend to supply for the next. If I now should
venture for the commendation of an unjust Steward,
and turn this Money to mine own use! ha! dear
Devil tempt me not. I will do thee service in a greater
Matter. But to rob the Poor! (a poor trick) every
Church-warden can do it. Now something whispers
me, that my Master, for his Stewards love, will supply
the Poor, as I may handle the matter. Then I
rob the Steward, if I restore him not the Money at
his return. Away Temptation, leave me. I am frail
flesh: yet I will fight with thee. But say the Steward
never return. O but he will return. Perhaps he may
not return. Turn from me Satan: strive not to clog
my conscience. I would not have this weight upon it
for all thy Kingdom.

sp.l: Hey down hay down a down etc.
Remember, Sir, your Covenant to be merry.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I strive you see to be so.
Yet something pricks me within, methinks.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: No further thought, I hope, of Fortunes tell-tales.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I think not of them. Nor will I presage,
That when a disposition of sadness
Overclouds my spirits, I shall therefore hear
Ill news, or shortly meet with some disaster.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Nay, when a man meets with bad tidings, why
May not he then compel his mind to mirth;
As well as puling stomachs are made strong
By eating against Appetite?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Forced Mirth though is not good.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: It relishes not you will say. No more does Meat
That is most savoury to a long sick stomach,
Until by Strife and Custom it is made good.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: You argue well. But do you see yond Fellow?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I never noted him so sad before.
He neither sings nor whistles.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Something troubles him.
Can he force Mirth out of himself now, think you?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: What speak you of a Clod of Earth; a Hind?
But one degree above a Beast, compared
To the aery spirit of a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: He looks, as he came laden with ill news,
To meet me on my way.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: It is very pretty.
Suppose the Ass be tired with sadness: will you disburden him
To load yourself? Think of your Covenant to be merry
In spite of Fortune and her riddle-makers.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Why how now Randal! sad? where is Springlove?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: He is ever in his Care. But that I know
The old Squire's virtue, I should think Springlove
Were sure his Bastard.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Here is his Money, Sir.
I pray that I be charged with it no longer.
sp.p:
The Devil and I have strained courtesy these two
hours about it. I would not be corrupted with the
trust of more than is mine own. Master. Steward gave
it me, Sir, to order it for the Beggars. He has made
me Steward of the Barn and them, while he is gone
(he says) a Journey, to survey and measure Lands
abroad about the Countries. Some purchase I think
for your Worship.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I know his measuring of Land. He is gone his old way.
And let him go. Am not I merry Hearty?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Yes; but not hearty merry. There is a whim now.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: The Poor's charge shall be mine. Keep you the Money for him.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Mine is the greater charge then.
Knew you but my temptations and my care,
You would discharge me of it.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I have not had it so many minutes, as I have
been in several Minds about it; and most of them
dishonest.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Go then, and give to one of my Daughters
to keep for Springlove.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: O, I thank your Worship --

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Alas poor knave! How hard a task it is to alter Custom!

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: And how easy for Money to corrupt it.
What a pure Treasurer would he make!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: All were not born for weighty Offices.
Which makes me think of Springlove.
He might have taken his leave though.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I hope he is run away with some large Trust,
I never liked such demure down-looked Fellows.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: You are deceived in him.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: If you be not it is well. But this is from the Covenant.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Well Sir. I will be merry. I am resolved
To force my Spirit only unto Mirth.
Should I hear now, my Daughters were misled
Or run away, I would not send a sigh
To fetch them back.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: The other old Song for that.
THere was an old fellow at Waltham Cross,
Who merrily sung when he lived by the Loss.
He never was heard to sigh with Hey-ho:
But sent it out with a Heigh trolly lo.
He cheered up his Heart, when his Goods went to wrack,
With a heghm boy, heghm, and a Cup of old Sack.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Is that the way of it? well, it shall me mine then.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: My Mistresses are both abroad, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: How? since when?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
On foot, Sir, two hours since, with the two
Gentlemen their Lovers. Here is a Letter they left
with the Butler. And there is a muttering in the
House.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I will not read, nor open it; but conceive
Within myself the worst, that can befall them;
That they are lost and no more mine. What follows?
That I am happy: all my cares are flown.
The Counsel I anticipated from
My friend, shall serve to set my Rest upon
(Without all further helps) to jovial Mirth:
Which I will force out of my spleen so freely,
That Grief shall lose her name, where I have being;
And sadness, from my furthest foot of Land,
While I have life, be banished.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: What is the whim now?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My Tenants shall sit Rent-free for this twelve-month;
And all my servants have their wages doubled;
And so shall be my charge in House-keeping.
I hope my friends will find and put me to it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: For them I will be your Undertaker, Sir.
But this is over-done. I do not like it.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: And for thy news, the Money that thou hast,
Is now thine own. I will make it good to Springlove.
Be sad with it and leave me. For I tell thee,
I will purge my house of stupid melancholy.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I will be as merry as the Charge that is under me

div2.stage:
A confused noyse within of laughing and singing, and
one crying out.

sp.l: The Beggars, Sir. Do ye hear them in the Barn?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I will double their allowance too; that they may
Double their Numbers, and increase their Noise:
These Bear not sound enough: and one (methought)
Cried out among them.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: By a most natural Cause. For there is a Doxy
Has been in labour, Sir. And it is their Custom,
With songs and shouts to drown the woman's cries.
A Ceremony which they use, not for
Devotion, but to keep off Notice of
The Work, they have in hand. Now she is in
The straw it, seems; and they are quiet.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
The straw! that is very proper there. That is
Randal's whim.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: We will have such a lying in, and such
A Christening; such up-fitting and Gossipping!
I mean to send forty miles Circuit at the least,
To draw in all the Beggars can be found;
And such Devices we will have for jollity,
As Fame shall boast to all Posterity.
Am I not merry Hearty? hearty merry?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Would you were else. I fear this over-doing.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: I will do it for expiation of a crime
That is charged upon my Conscience till it be done.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: What is that? what says he?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: We will have such a Festival month of it, Randall --

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Sir, you may spare the labour and the cost:
They will never thank you for it. They will not endure
A Ceremony, that is not their own,
Belonging either to the Child, or Mother.
A month Sir? They will not be detained so long
For your Estate. Their Work is done already:
The Bratling is born, the Doxy is in the Strummel,
Laid by an Autem Mort of their own Crew,
That served for Mid-wife: and the Child-bed woman
Eating of hasty Pudding for her supper,
And the Child part of it for pap
I warrant you by this time; then to sleep;
So to rise early to regain the strength
By travail, which she lost by travail.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: There is Randal again.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
She will have the Bantling at her back tomorrow
That was today in her belly, and march a foot-back
with it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Art there again, old Randal?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: And for this Gossipping (now you are so nigh)
If you will look in, I doubt not, but you will find them
At their high Feast already.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Pray let us see them, Sir.

div2.stage:
Randal opens the Scene. The Beggars discovered at
their Feast. After they have scrambled a while
at their Victuals: This Song.

sp.l: HEre, safe in our Skipper, let us cly off our Peck,
And bowse in defiance of the Harman-beck.
Here is Pannum and Lap, and good Poplars of Yarrum,
To fill up the Crib, and to comfort the Quarron.
Now bowse a round health to the Go-well and Com-well
Of Cisley Bumtrincket that lies in the Strummel.
Now bowse a round health to the Go-well and Com-well
Of Cisley Bumtrincket that lies in the Strummel.
Here is Russpeck and Casson, and all of the best,
And Scraps of the Dainties of Gentry Cose's Feast.
Here is Grunter and Bleater, with Tib of the Buttery,
And Margery Prater, all dressed without fluttery.
For all this been Cribbing and Peck let us then,
Bowse a health to the Gentry Cos of the Ken.
Now bowse a health to the Go-well and Com-well
Of Cisley Bumtrincket that lies in the Strummel.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Good Heaven how merry they are.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Be not you sad at that.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Sad Hearty, no unless it be with envy
At their full happiness. What is an Estate
Of Wealth and Power, balanced with their Freedom,
But a mere load of outward complement?
When they enjoy the Fruits of rich Content?
Our Dross but weighs us down into Despair,
While their sublimed spirits dance in the Air.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: I have not so much Wealth to weigh me down,
Nor so little (I thank Chance ) as to dance naked.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: True my Friend Hearty, thou having less than I,
(Of which I boast not) art the merrier man:
But they exceed thee in that way so far,
That should I know, my Children now were Beggars
(Which yet I will not read) I must conclude,
They were not lost, nor I to be aggrieved.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: If this be madness, it is a merry Fit.

div2.stage: Enter Patrico. many of the Beggars look out.

sp.speaker: Patrico.
sp.l: Tour out with your Glasiers, I swear by the Ruffian,
That we are assaulted by a quire Cuffin.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: HOld! what do ye mean, my Friends? This is our Master,
The Master of your Feast and feasting-House.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Is this the Gentry Cos?

sp.speaker: All the Beggars.
sp.p:
Lord bless his Worship. His good
Worship. Bless his Worship.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Now, bounteous Sir, before you go,
Hear me, the Beggar Patrico;
Or Priest, if you do rather choose,
That we no word of Canting use.
Long may you live, and may your Store
Never decay, nor balk the Poor:
And as you more in years do grow,
May Treasure to your Coffers flow;
And may your care no more thereon
Be set, than ours are, that have none:
But as your Riches do increase,
So may your hearts Content and Peace.
And, after many, many years,
When the Poor have quit their Fears
Of losing you; and that with Heaven
And all the world you have made even,
Then may your blessed Posterity,
Age after Age successively,
Until the world shall be untwined
Inherit your Estate and Mind.
So shall the Poor to the last day,
For you, in your succession, pray.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
It is a good Vote, Sir Patrico: but you are
too grave. Let us hear and see something of your
merry Grigs, that can sing, play Gambols, and do
Feats.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Sir, I can lay my Function by,
And talk as wild and wantonly
As Tom or Tib, or Jack, or Jill,
When they at Bowsing Ken do swill.
Will you therefore deign to hear
My Autem Mort, with throat as clear,
As was Dame Anisses of the Name;
How sweet in Song her Notes she will frame,
That when she chides, as loud is yawning,
As Chanticlere waked by the dawning.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Yes, pray let us hear her. What is she your wife?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Yes Sir. We of our Ministry,
As well as those of the Presbytery,
Take wives and defy Dignity.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: A learned Clerk in verity!

div2.stage:
Enter Patrico with his old wife, with a wooden Bowle
of Drink, She is drunk.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: By Salmon, I think my Mort is in drink.
I find by her stink; and the pretty pretty pink
Of her Neyes, that half wink,
That the tippling Feast, with the Doxy in the Nest,
Hath turned her brain, to a merry merry vain.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
Go Fiddle Patrico, and let me sing. First set
me down here on both my Prates. Gently, gently, for
cracking of my wind, now I must use it. Hem hem.

sp.l: THis is Bien Bowse, this is Bien Bowse,
Too little is my Skew.
I bowse no Lage, but a whole Gage
Of this I will bowse to you.
This Bowse is better than Rom-bowse,
It sets the Gan a-giggling;
The Autem-Mort finds better sport
In bowsing than in niggling.
This is Bien-bowse etc.

div2.stage: She tosses off her Bowle, falls back, and is carried out.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: So so: your part is done --

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: How find you, Sir, yourself?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Wondrous merry, my good Hearty.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: I wish we had, in all our store,
Something that could please you more.
The old or Autem-Mort is asleep;
But before the young ones creep
Into the straw, Sir, if you are,
(As Gallants sometimes love course fare,
(So it be fresh and wholesome Ware)
Disposed to Doxy, or a Dell,
That never yet with man did Mell;
Of whom no Upright man is taster,
I will present her to you, Master.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Away. You would be punished. O.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: How is it with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
A sudden qualm over-chills my stomach. But
it will away.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: See, in their rags, then, dancing for your sports,
Our Clapper Dungeons and their walking Morts.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: You have done well. Now let each Tripper
Make a retreat into the Skipper;
And couch a Hogs-head, till the darkmandarkman is past;
Then all with Bag and Baggage bing awast.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: I told you, Sir, they would be gone tomorrow.
I understand their canting.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Take that amongst you. --

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: May rich Plenty so you bless,
Though you still give, you never have less.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: And as your walks may lead this way:
Pray strike in here another day.
So you may go, Sir Patrico --
sp.p:
How think you, Sir? or what? or why do you think
at all, unless on Sack and Supper-time? do you fall
back? do you not know the danger of relapses?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Good Hearty, thou mistakest me. I was thinking
upon this Patrico. And that he has more soul
than a born Beggar in him.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Rogue enough though, to offer us his what-d'ecalts?
his Doxies. Heart and cup of Sack, do we
look like old Beggar-nigglers?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Pray forbear that Language.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Will you then talk of Sack, that can drown
sighing? will you in, to supper, and take me there
your Guest? Or must I creep into the Barn among
your welcome ones?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
You have rebuked me timely; and most
friendly.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Would all were well with him.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: It is with me.
For now these pounds are (as I feel them swag)
Light at my heart, though heavy in the bag.

div1.stage: Vincent and Hilliard in their Rags.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Is this the life that we admired in others; with
envy at their happiness?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Pray let us make virtuous use of it: and repent
us of that deadly sin (before a greater punishment
than Famine and Lice fall upon us) by steering
our course homeward. Before I will endure such another
night --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
what? what wouldst thou do? I would thy
Mistress heard thee.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
I hope she does not. For I know there is no
altering our course before they make the first motion.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Is it possible we should be weary already?
and before their softer constitutions of flesh and
blood?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: They are the stronger in will it seems.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
How now Comrades! repining already at your
fullness of Liberty? Do you complain of ease?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Ease call'st thou it? Didst thou sleep tonight?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Not so well these eighteen months I swear; since
my last walks.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Lightning and Tempest is out of thy Litany.
Could not the thunder wake thee?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Ha. ha ha.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Nor the noise of the Crew in the Quarter by
us?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Nor the Hogs in the hovel, that cried till they
drowned the noise of the wind?

If I could but once have dreamt in all my former
nights, that such an affliction could have been found
among Beggars, sure I should never have travelled to
the proof of it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
We looked upon them in their Jollity, and
cast no further.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Nor did that only draw us forth (by your
favour Vince ) but our obedience to our Loves, which
we must suffer, till they cry home again. Are they
not weary yet, as much as we dost think Springlove?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
They have more moral understanding than
so. They know (and so may you) this is your Birth-night
into a new world. And we all know (or have
been told) that all come crying into the World,
when the whole World of Pleasures is before us.
The World itself had never been glorious, had it not
first been a confused Chaos.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Well: never did Knight Errants in all Adventures
merit more of their Ladies, than we Beggar-errants
or errant Beggars, do in ours.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
The greater will be your Reward. Think
upon that. And show no manner of distaste to turn
their hearts from you. You are undone then.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Are they ready to appear out of their privy
Lodgings, in the Pigs Palace of pleasure? Are they
coming forth?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I left them almost ready, sitting on their Pads
of straw, helping to dress each others heads (The
ones eye is the tothers Looking-glass) with the prettiest
coil they keep to fit their fancies in the most
graceful way of wearing their new Dressings, that
you would admire.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I hope we are as gracefully set out. Are we
not?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Indifferent well. But will you fall to practise?
Let me hear how you can Maund when you meet
with Passengers.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
We do not look like men, I hope, too good
to learn.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Suppose some Persons of Worth or Wealth
passing by now. Note me. Good your good Worship,
your Charity to the Poor, that will duly and
truly pray for you day and night. --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Away you idle Rogue, you would be set to
work and whipped --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That is lame and sick; hungry and comfortless --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: If you were well served --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
And even to bless you and reward you for
it --

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Prithee hold thy peace (here be doleful
Notes indeed) and leave us to our own Genius. If we
must beg, let us let it go, as it comes, by Inspiration. I
love not your set form of Begging.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Let me instruct ye though.

div1.stage: Enter Rachel and Meriel in Rags.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Have a care, good Meriel, what hearts or
limbs soever we have, and though never so feeble, let
us set our best faces of it, and laugh our last gasp out
before we discover any dislike, or weariness to them.
Let us bear it out, till they complain first, and beg
to carry us home a pick pack.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
I am sorely surbated with hoosing already
though, and so crupper-crampt with our hard lodging,
and so bumfidled with the straw, that --

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Think not on it. I am numbed in the bum and
shoulders too a little. And have found the difference
between a hard floor with a little straw, and a down
Bed with a Quilt upon it. But no words, not a sour
look I prithee.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
O here they come now; Madam Fewcloaths,
and my Lady Bonnyrag.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Peace, they see us.

sp.speaker: Ra. Mer.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: We are glad the Object pleases ye.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: So does the Subject.
Now you appear the glories of the Spring,
Darlings of Phoebus and the Somers heirs.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.l: How fairer, than fair Floras self appear
(To deck the Spring) Diana's Darlings dear!
O let us now Acteon-like be struck
(With greedy eyes while we presume to look
On your half nakedness, since courteous rags
Cover the rest) into the shape of Stags.

sp.speaker: Ra. Mer.
sp.p:
Ha ha ha -- We are glad you are so
merry.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Merry and lusty too. This night will we lie
together as well as the proudest Couple in the Barn.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: And so will we. I can hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Does the straw stir up your flesh to it, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Or does your Provender prick you?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: What! do we come for this? laugh and lie down
When your bellies are full. Remember, Ladies,
You have not begged yet, to quit your Destiny:
But have lived hitherto on my endeavours.
Who got your suppers, pray, last night, but I?
Of dainty Trencher-Fees, from a Gentleman's house:
Such as the Serving-men themselves, sometimes,
Would have been glad of. And this morning now,
What comfortable Chippings and sweet Buttermilk
Had you to Breakfast!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O it was excellent! I feel it good still, here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
There was a brown Crust amongst it, that
has made my neck so white methinks. Is it not Rachel?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes. You gave me none of it. You ever covet to have all the Beauty.
sp.l: It is the ambition of all younger Sisters.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: They are pleased, and never like to be weary.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.l: No more must we, if we will be theirs.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Peace. Here come Passengers. Forget not
your Rules; and quickly disperse yourselves, and
fall to your Calling --

Lead the Horses down the Hill. The heat of
our speed is over, for we have lost our Journey.

Had they taken this way, we had overtaken
them, or heard of them at least.

But some of our Scouts will light on them, the
whole Country being overspread with them.
There was never such an escape else.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
A search for us perhaps. Yet I know not
them, nor they me, I am sure. I might the better
beg of them. But how to begin, or set the worst leg
forwards, would I were whipped if I know now.

That a young Gentlewoman of her breeding,
and Heir to such an Estate, should fly from so great
a match, and run away with her Uncles Clerk!
The old Justice will run mad upon it I fear.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
If I were to be hanged now, I could not beg
for my life.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Step forwards, and beg handsomely. I will set
my Goad in your breech else.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Have I not told you? now begin.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: After you, good Springlove.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Good your good Worships. --
Away you idle Vagabond --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Your Worships Charity to a poor Creature welly
starved.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: That will duly and truly pray for ye.
You counterfeit Villains, hence.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Good Masters, sweet Worship, for the teacher mercy
of --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.p:
You would be well whipped and set to work, if
you were duly and truly served.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Did not I say so before?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Good Worshipful Masters Worship, to bestow
your Charity, and -- to maintain your health and
Limbs.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.p: Be gone, I say, you impudent lusty young Rascals.
I will set you going else.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Ah the goodness of compassion to soften your
hearts to the poor.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
O the Devil, must not we beat them now?
steth --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Nor show an angry look for all the skin of
our backs. Ah the sweetness of that mercy that gives
to all, to move your compassion to the hungry, when
it shall seem good unto you, and night and day, to
bless all that you have. Ah ah --

Come back sirrah. His Patience and Humility
has wrought upon me.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Duly and --

Not you sirrah. The other. You look like a
sturdy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Lord bless you Masters Worship.

There is a half-penny for you. Let him have
no share with you.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I shall never thrive on this Trade.

They are of a Fraternity, and will share, I warrant
you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Never in our lives trooly. He never begged
with me before.

But if Hedges or Hen-roosts could speak, you
might be found sharers in Pillage, I believe.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Never saw him before, bless your good Master,
in all my life. (Beg for yourself. Your Credit is
gone else.) Good Heaven to bliss and prosper yea.

Why dost thou follow us? Is it your office to
be privy to our talk?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Sir, I beseech you hear me. ('slife what shall I
say?) I am a stranger in these parts, and destitute of
Means and Apparel.
So methinks. And what of that?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l:
Will you therefore be pleased, or you are worthy
Gentlemen, and blessed with plenty --

sp.p: This is Courtly!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Out of your abundant store, towards my relief in
extreme necessity, to furnish me with a small parcel of
Money -- five or six pieces, or ten, if you can presently
spare it.
Stand off.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I have spoiled all; and know not how to beg
otherwise.
Here is a new way of begging!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Quite run out of my Instructions.

Some High-way Thief on my conscience, that
forgets he is weaponless.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
only to make you merry, Gentlemen, at
my unskilfulness in my new Trade. I have been another
man in my days. So I kiss your hands.
With your heels do you?

It had been good to have apprehended the
Rakeshame. There is some mystery in his Rags. But
let him go.

div1.stage: Enter Oliver, putting up his sword.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
You found your legs in time, I had made you
halt for something else.

Master Oliver, well returned; what is the matter,
Sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, a counterfeit lame Rogue begged of
me; but in such Language, the high Sheriffs Son of
the Shire could not have spoke better; nor to have
borrowed a greater sum. (He asked me if I could
spare him ten or twenty pound.) I switched him, his
Cudgel was up. I drew, and into the Wood he scaped
me, as nimbly -- But first he told me, I should hear
from him by a Gentleman, to require satisfaction of
me.

We had such another begged of us. The Court
goes a-begging, I think.

Dropped through the Clouds, I think; more Lucifers
travailing to Hell, that beg by the way. Met
you no news of the Kinswoman, Mistress Amie?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
No. What is the matter with her? Goes her
Marriage forwards with young Master Talboy? I hastened
my Journey from London to be at the Wedding.

It was to have been yesterday morning; all things
in readiness prepared for it. But the Bride, stolen by
your Father's Clerk, is slipped away. We were in quest
of them, and so are twenty more, several ways.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Such young Wenches will have their own
ways in their own loves, what Matches soever their
Guardians make for them. And I hope my Father will
not follow the Law so close to hang his Clerk for
stealing his Ward with her own consent. It may
breed such a grudge, may cause some Clerks to hang
their Masters, that have them of the hip of injustice.
Besides, Martin (though he be his servant) is a Gentleman.
But, indeed, the miserablest Rascal! He
will grudge her Meat when he has her.

Your Father is exceedingly troubled at their
escape. I wish that you may qualify him with your
Reasons.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
But what says TAlboy to the matter, the Bridegroom,
that should have been?

Marry he says little to the purpose; but cries
outright.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
I like him well for that: He holds his humour.
A miserable wretch too, though rich. I have known him
cry when he has lost but three shillings at Mumchance.
But, Gentlemen, keep on your way to comfort
my Father. I know some of his Man's private
haunts about the Country here, which I will search
immediately.
We will accompany you, if you please.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: No, by no means! That will be too public.
Do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
My pleasure, and all the search that I intend,
is, by hovering here, to take a review of a brace of
the handsomest Beggar-braches that ever graced a
Ditch or a Hedge side. I past by them in haste, but something
so possesses me, that I must -- What the Devil
must I? A Beggar? Why, Beggars are flesh and blood;
and Rags are no Diseases. Their Lice are no French
Fleas, And there is much wholesomer flesh under
Country Dirt, than City Painting: And less danger
in Dirt and Rags, than in Ceruse and Satin. I durst
not take a touch at London, both for the present cost,
and fear of an after-reckoning. But Oliver, dost thou
speak like a Gentleman? fear Price or Pox, ha? Marry
do I Sir: Nor can Beggar-sport be inexcusable in a
young Country Gentleman, short of means, for another
respect, a principal one indeed; to avoid the
punishment or charge of Bastardy: There is no commuting
with them; or keeping of Children for them.
The poor Whores, rather than part with their own,
or want children at all, will steal other folks, to travel
with, and move compassion. He feeds a Beggar-wench
well that fills her belly with young bones. And
these reasons considered, good Master Oliver -- 'slid
yonder they are at peep. And now sitten down as
waiting for my purpose.

Heart
here is another delay. I must shift him. Dost hear
honest poor fellow? I prithee go back presently:
and at the hill foot (here is sixpence for thy pains)
thou shalt find a Footman with a Horse in his hand.
Bid him wait there. His Master will come presently,
say.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Sir, I have a business of another nature to
you. Which (as I presume you are a Gentleman of
right Noble Spirit and Resolution) you will receive
without offence; and in that temper as most properly
appertains to the most Heroic natures.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Thy Language makes me wonder at thy Person.
What is the matter with thee? quickly.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
You may be pleased to call to mind a late
affront, which, in your heat of passion, you gave a
Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What, such a one as thou art, was he?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
True noble Sir. Who could no less in Honour,
than direct me, his chosen Friend, unto you,
with the length of his Sword, or to take the length
of yours. The place, if you please, the Ground
whereon you parted; the hour, seven the next morning:
Or, if you like not these, in part, or all, to
make your own appointments.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
The bravest Method in Beggars, that ever was
discovered! I would be upon the bones of this Rogue
now, but for crossing my other design, which fires
me. I must therefore be rid of him on my terms. Let
his own Appointments stand. Tell him I will meet
him.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
You shall most nobly engage his life to serve
you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You will be his Second, will you?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
To do you further Service, Sir, I have undertaken
it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I will send a Beadle shall undertake you both.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Your Mirth becomes the bravery of your
mind and dauntless Spirit. So takes his leave your
Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
I think, as my Friend said, the Court goes a-begging
indeed. But I must not lose my Beggar-wenches.

O here they come. They are delicately skinned
and limbed. There, there, I saw above the ham as
the wind blew. Now they spy me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Sir, I beseech you look upon us with the favour
of a Gentleman. We are in a present distress,
and utterly unacquainted in these parts; and therefore
forced by the Calamity of our misfortune, to
implore the Courtesy, or rather Charity, of those to
whom we are strangers.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Very fine, this!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Be therefore pleased, right noble Sir, not
only valuing us by our outward Habits, which cannot
but appear loathsome or despicable unto you, but
as we are forlorn Christians; and, in that estimation,
be compassionately moved to cast a handful or
two of your Silver, or a few of your Golden Pieces
unto us, to furnish us with Linen, and some decent
Habiliments --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
They beg as high as the Man-beggar I met
withal! sure the Beggars are all mad today, or bewitched
into a Language they understand not. The
spirits of some decayed Gentry talk in them sure.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
May we expect a gracious Answer from you
Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And that as you can wish our Virgin Prayers
to be propitious for you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That you never be denied a Suit by any Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nay, that the fairest may be ambitious to
place their favours on you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
That your Virtue and Valour may lead you
to the most honourable Actions; and that the Love
of all exquisite Ladies may arm you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And that, when you please to take a wife,
may Honour, Beauty, and Wealth, contend to endow
her most with.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
And that with her you have a long and prosperous
life.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A fair and fortunate Posterity.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
This exceeds all that ever I heard, and strikes
me into wonder. Pray tell me how long have you
been Beggars; or how chanced you to be so?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: By influence of our Stars, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: We were born, to no better Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
How came you to talk thus, and so much above
the Beggars Dialect?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Our speech came naturally to us, and we ever
loved to learn by wrote as well as we could.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And to be ambitious above the vulgar, to
ask more than common Alms, whatever men please
to give us.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Sure some well disposed Gentleman, as myself,
got these Wenches. They are too well grown to be
mine own, and I cannot be incestuous with them.

sp.speaker: Ra.
