sp.p: Pray sir your noble bounty.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
What a tempting lip that little Rogue moves
there! and what an enticing eye the tother. I know
not which to begin with. What is this a flea upon thy
bosom?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Is it not a straw coloured one, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
O what a provoking Skin is there! that very
touch inflames me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, are you moved in charity towards us yet?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Moved? I am moved. No flesh and blood more
moved.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then pray Sir your Benevolence.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Benevolence? which shall I be benevolent to;
or which first? I am puzzled in the choice. Would
some sworn Brother of mine were here to draw a
Cut with me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
First let me tell you, Damsels, I am bound by a
strong vow to kiss all the woman sex I meet this
morning.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Beggars and all Sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
All, all. Let not your coyness cross a Gentleman's
vow, I beseech you --

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You will tell how.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Tell quoth he! I could tell a thousand on those
Lips -- and as many upon those. What life restoring
breaths they have! Milk from the Cow steams
not so sweetly. I must lay one of them abroad; both if
my tackling hold.

sp.speaker: Ra. Mer.
sp.p: Sir. Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
But how to bargain, now, will be the doubt.
They that beg so high as by the handfuls, may expect
for price above the rate of good men's wives.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Now, will you, Sir, be pleased?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
With all my heart, Sweetheart. And I am
glad thou knowest my mind. Here is twelve-pence
a piece for you.

sp.speaker: Ra. Me.
sp.p: We thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
That is but in earnest. I will Jest away the rest
with ye. Look here -- All this. Come, you know
my meaning. Dost thou look about thee, Sweet little
Ones? I like thy care. There is nobody coming.
But we will get behind these Bushes. I know you keep
each others Counsels -- Must you be drawn to it?
Then I will pull. Come away --

sp.speaker: Ra. Me.
sp.p: Ah ah --

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Let us beat his brains out.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Come leave your squealing.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: O you hurt my hand.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Or cut the Lechers throat.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Would you be hanged? Stand back. Let me
alone.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: You shall not pull us so.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: O do not hurt them, Master.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Hurt them? I meant them but too well. Shall I
be so prevented?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
They be but young and simple. And if they
have offended, let not your Worships own hands
drag them to the Law, or carry them to Punishment.
Correct them not yourself. It is the Beadles Office.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Do you talk Shake-rag: Heart yond is more
of them. I shall be Beggar-mauled if I stay. Thou
sayst right, honest fellow, there is a Tester for thee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: He is prevented, and ashamed of his purpose.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Nor were we to take notice of his purpose
more than to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
True, politic Springlove, it was better his
own fear quit us of him, than our force.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Look you here, Gentlemen, twelve pence a
piece.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Besides fair offers and large promises. What
have you got today, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
More than (as we are Gentlemen) we would
have taken.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yet we put it up in your Service.

sp.speaker: Ra. Mer.
sp.p:
Ha ha ha. Switches and kicks. Ha ha
ha --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Talk not here of your gettings. We must quit
this Quarter. The eager Gentleman's repulse may
arm and return him with revenge upon us. We must
therefore leap Hedge and Ditch now; through the
Briers and Mires, till we scape out of this Liberty,
to our next Rendezvous; where we shall meet the
Crew, and then, hay toss and laugh all night.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: As we did last night.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hold out, Meriel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Lead on, brave General.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
What shall we do? They are in heart still.
Shall we go on?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: There is no flinching back, you see.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Besides, if you beg no better than you begin,
in this lofty Fashion, you cannot scape the Jail, or
the whip, long.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
To tell you true, it is not the least of my purpose,
to work means for our discovery, to be released
out of our Trade.

div1.stage: Enter Martin and Amie in poor Habits.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Stay, here come more Passengers, Single
yourselves again, and fall to your Calling discreetly.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
I will single no more. If you will beg in full cry
I am for you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Aye that will be fine; let us charm all together.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Stay first and list a little.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Be of good cheer, Sweetheart, we have
scaped hitherto: And I believe that all the Search is
now retired, and we may safely pass forwards.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
I should be safe with thee. But that is a most
lying Proverb, that says, Where Love is, there is no
Lack. I am faint, and cannot travail further without
Meat; and if you loved me, you would get me some.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
We will venture at the next Village to call for
some. The best is, we want no Money.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
We shall be taken then, I fear. I will rather
pine to death.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Be not so fearful. Who can know us in
these Clownish Habits?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Our Clothes, indeed, are poor enough to beg
with. Would I could beg, so it were of Strangers
that could not know me, rather than buy of those
that would betray us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And yonder be some that can teach us.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
These are the young couple of Run-away
Lovers disguised, that the Country is so laid for.
Observe and follow more. Now the Lord to come with
ye, good loving Master and Mistress, your blessed Charity
to the poor, lame and sick, weak and comfortless,
that will night and day --

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p:
Duly and truly pray for you. Duly and truly pray
for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Pray hold your peace, and let me alone. Good
young Master and Mistress, a little Comfort amongst us all,
and to bless you wherever you go, and

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Duly and truly pray for you. Duly and truly --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Pray do not use me thus. Now sweet young
Master and Mistress, to look upon your Poor, that have
no relief or succour, no bread to put in our heads.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Wouldst thou put Bread in thy Brains?
No Lands or Livings.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
No House nor home; nor covering from the
cold; no health, no help but your sweet Charity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No Bands or Shirts but lousy on our backs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No smocks or Petticoats to hide our Scratches.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No Shoes to our Legs, or Hose to our Feet.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
No skin to our Flesh, nor Flesh to our Bones
shortly.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
If we follow the Devil that taught us
to beg.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I will run away from you if you beg a stroke
more. Good worshipful Master and Mistress --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Good Friend forbear. Here is no Master or
Mistress. We are poor Folks. Thou seest no Worship
upon our backs, I am sure. And for within, we
want as much as you, and would as willingly beg, if
we knew how as well.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Alack for pity. You may have enough.
And what I have is yours, if you will accept it. It is
wholesome Food from a good Gentleman's Gate --
Alas good Mistress -- Much good do your heart.
How savourly she feeds!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What do you mean; to poison yourself?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Do you show Love in grudging me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay, if you think it hurts you not, fall to.
I will not beguile you. And here, mine Host, something
towards your Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: This Beggar is an Angel sure!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Nothing by way of bargain, gentle Master.
It is against Order, and will never thrive. But pray,
Sir, your reward in Charity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Here then in Charity. This fellow would
never make a Clerk.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What! All this, Master?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: What is it? Let me see it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: It is a whole silver three-pence, Mistress.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
For shame, ingrateful Miser. Here Friend,
a golden Crown for thee.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Bountiful Goodness! Gold? If I thought
a dear year were coming, I would take a Farm now.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
I have robbed thy Partners of their shares too.
There is a Crown more for them.
Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
What have you done? less would have
served. And your Bounty will betray us.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Fie on your wretched policy.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
No, no good Master. I knew you all this
while, and my sweet Mistress too. And now I will tell
you. The Search is every way; the Country all laid
for you. It is well you staid here. Your Habits,
were they but a little nearer our Fashion, would secure
you with us. But are you married, Master and
Mistress? Are you joined in Matrimony? In heart I
know you are. And I will (if it please you) for
your great bounty, bring you to a Curate, that
lacks no License, nor has any Living to lose, that
shall put you together.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou art a heavenly Beggar!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
But he is scrupulous, and severely precise,
that unless you, Mistress, will affirm that you are
with Child by the Gentleman; or that you have, at
least, cleft or slept together (as he calls it) he will
not marry you. But if you have lain together, then
it is a case of necessity, and he holds himself bound
to do it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You may say you have.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
I would not have it so, nor make that lie
against myself for all the World.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That I like well, and her exceedingly.
I will do my best for you however.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I will do for thee, that -- thou shalt never beg
more.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
That cannot be purchased scarce for the price
of your Mistress. Will you walk, Master? -- We use
no Complements.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: By enforced Matches Wards are not set free
So oft, as sold into Captivity:
Which made me, fearless, fly from one I hate,
Into the hazard of a harder Fate.

div2.stage: Enter Talboy. Oliver. With riding Switches.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.l: She is gone. Amie is gone. Aye me she is gone,
sp.p:
And has me left of joy bereft, to make my
moan. O me, Amie.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
What the Devil ails the Fellow trow? why!
why Master Talboy; my Cozen Talboy that shouldst
have been, art not ashamed to cry at this growth? and
for a thing that is better lost than found; a Wench?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Cry! Who cries? do I cry; or look with a
crying Countenance? I scorn it; and scorn to think
on her, but in just anger.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: So, this is brave now, if it would hold.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p:
Nay it shall hold. And so let her go, for a
scurvy what do ye call it; I know not what bad enough
to call her. -- But something of mine goes with
her I am sure. She has cost me in Gloves, Ribands,
Scarfs, Rings, and such like things, more than I am
able to speak of at this time -- O.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Because thou canst not speak for crying. Fie
Master Talboy, again?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I scorn it again, and any man that says I cry,
or will cry again. And let her go again; and what she
has of mine let her keep, and hang herself, and the
Rogue that is with her. I have enough; and am
Heir of a well-known Estate, and that she knows --
And therefore that she should sleight me, and run
away with a wages-fellow, that is but a petty Clerk
and a Serving-man. There is the vexation of it -- O
there is the grief, and the vexation of it -- O --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Now he will cry his eyes out! You Sir. This
life have I had with you all our long journey; which
now is at an end here. This is Master Oldrents house,
where perhaps we shall find old Hearty, the Uncle
of that Rogue Martin, that is run away with your
Sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Aye it is too true, too true, too true. You need
not put me in mind of it -- O -- O

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Hold your peace and mind me. Leave your
bawling, for fear I give you correction. This is the
House I say, where it is most likely we shall hear of
your Mistress and her companion. Make up your face
quickly. Here comes one of the Servants, I suppose.

Shame not yourself forever, and me for company.
Come, be confident.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p:
As confident as yourself or any man -- But
my poor heart feels what lies here. Here. aye here it
is, O --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Good morrow, Friend. This is Squire Oldrents
House, I take it.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Pray take it not, Sir, before it be to be let.
It has been my Masters, and his Ancestors in that
Name, above these three hundred years, as our
House Chronicle doth notify; and not yet to be let.
But as a Friend, or stranger, in Guest-wise, you are
welcome to it; as all other Gentlemen are, far and
near, to my good Master, as you will find anon when
you see him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Thou speakest wittily and honestly. But I prithee,
good Friend, let our Nags be set up: they are
tied up at the post. You belong to the Stable, do
you not?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Not so much, as the Stable belongs to me,
Sir. I pass through many Offices of the House, Sir.
I am the running Bailey of it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
We have rid hard, hoping to find the Squire
at home at this early time in the morning.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
You are deceived in that, Sir. He has been
out these four hours. He is no Snail, Sir. You do
not know him, I perceive, since he has been new
moulded. But I will tell you, because you are Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Our Horses, good Friend.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
My Master is an ancient Gentleman, and a
great House-keeper; and prayed for by all the Poor
in the Country. He keeps a Guest-house for all Beggars;
far and near, costs him a hundred a year, at
least; and is as well beloved among the Rich. But,
of late, he fell into a great Melancholy, upon what,
I know not: for he had then more cause to be merry
than he has now. Take that by the way.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: But good Friend, our Horses.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
For he had two Daughters, that knew well
to order a House, and give entertainment to Gentlemen.
They were his House-Doves. But now they
are flown; and no man knows how, why, or whither.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p: My Dove is flown too. O

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Was she your Daughter, Sir? She was a
young one then, by the Beard you wear.

sp.speaker: Tall.
sp.p:
What she was, she was, do ye see. I scorn to
think on her -- But I do -- O.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Pray hold your peace, or feign some mirth, if
you can.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Let her go, let her go. I care not if I
have her, I have her or no. Ha ha ha -- O my heart
will break -- O --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Pray think of our Horses, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
This is right my Master. When he had his
Daughters he was sad; and now they are gone, he is
the merriest man alive. Up at five a Clock in the
morning, and out till Dinner-time. Out again at afternoon,
and so till Supper-time. Skife out this away,
and skife out that away. (He is no Snail I assure
you.) and Tantivy all the Country over, where
Hunting, Hawking, or any Sport is to be made, or
good Fellowship to be had; and so merry upon all
occasions, that you would even bless yourself, if it
were possible.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Our Horses, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
And we, his Servants, live as merrily, under
him; and do all thrive. I myself was but a silly Lad
when I came first, a poor turn-spit Boy. Gentlemen
kept no whirling Jacks then, to cozen poor People
of Meat. And I have now, without boast, forty pound in
my Purse, and am the youngest of half a score in the
House, none younger than myself but one; and he
is the Steward over all; his name is Master Springlove
(bless him wherever he is) he has a world of
means: And we, the Underlings, get well the better
by him; besides the Rewards many Gentlemen
give us, that fare well, and lodge here sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
O! we shall not forget you, Friend, if you remember
our Horses, before they take harm.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
No hurt, I warrant you: there is a Lad walking
them.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Is not your Master coming, think you?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
He will not be long a-coming. He is no Snail,
as I told you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You told me so, indeed.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
But of all the Gentlemen, that toss up the
Ball, yea, and the Sack too, commend me to old Master
Hearty; a decayed Gentleman; lives most upon
his own Mirth, and my Masters Means, and much
good do him with it: He is the finest Companion of
all: He does so hold my Master up with Stories, and
Songs, and Catches, and the other Cup of Sack, and
such Tricks and Jigs, you would admire -- He is
with him now.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
That Hearty is Martins Uncle. I am glad he is
here. Bear up Talboy. Now, Friend, pray let me ask
you a question. -- Prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Nay, marry I dare not. Your Yawdes may
take cold, and never be good after it. --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
I thought I should never have been rid of him.
But no sooner desired to stay, but he is gone. A pretty
humour!

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, my Master will be here even
now, doubt not: for he is no Snail, as I told you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
No Snail is a great word with him. Prithee
Talboy bear up.

Here comes another
gray Fellow.

sp.speaker: Ush.
sp.p:
Do you stand in the Porch, Gentlemen? the
House is open to you. Pray enter the Hall. I am the
Usher of it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
In good time, Sir. We shall be bold here,
then, to attend your Masters coming.

sp.speaker: Ush.
sp.p:
And he is upon coming; and when he comes
he comes apace. He is no Snail, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
I was told so before, Sir. No Snail! sure it is
the word of the House, and as ancient as the Family.

sp.speaker: Ush.
sp.p: This Gentleman looks sadly, methinks.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Who I? not I. Pray pardon my looks for
that. But my heart feels what is what. Aye me --

sp.speaker: Ush.
sp.p:
Pray walk to the Buttery, Gentlemen. My
Office leads you thither.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Thanks, good Master Usher.

sp.speaker: Ush.
sp.p:
I have been Usher these twenty years, Sir.
And have got well by my place, for using Strangers
respectfully.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He has given the Hint too.

sp.speaker: Ush.
sp.p:
Something has come in by the by, besides
standing Wages, which is ever duly paid (thank a
good Master, and an honest Steward) Heaven bless
them. We all thrive under them.

div2.stage: Enter Butler with Glasses and a Napkin.

sp.p: O here comes the Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
You are welcome, Gentlemen. Please ye
draw nearer my Office, and take a morning Drink in
a Cup of Sack, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
In what please you, Sir. We cannot deny the
courtesy of the House, in the Masters absence.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
He will come apace when he comes. He is no
Snail, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Still it is the House-word. And all the Servants
wear Livery-Beards.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Or perhaps you had rather drink White wine
and Sugar. Please yourselves, Gentlemen; here
you may taste all Liquors. No Gentleman's House in
all this County, or the next, so well stored (-- make
us thankful for it.) And my Master, for his Hospitality
to Gentlemen, his Charity to the Poor, and
his bounty to his Servants, has not his Peer in the
Kingdom (-- make us thankful for it.) And it is as
fortunate a House for Servants, as ever was built upon
fairy-ground. I myself, that have served here,
Man, and Boy, these four and forty years, have gotten
together (besides something, more than I will
speak of, distributed among my poor Kindred) by
my Wages, my Veils at Christmas, and otherwise, together
with my Rewards of kind Gentlemen, that
have found courteous entertainments here --

sp.speaker: l. Ol.
sp.p: There he is too.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Have, I say, gotten together (though in a dangerous
time I speak it) a brace of hundred pounds --
Make me thankful for it. And for losses, I have had
none. I have been Butler these two and thirty years,
and never lost the value of a Silver Spoon, nor ever
broke a Glass -- Make me thankful for it. White
Wine and Sugar, say you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Please yourself, Sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
This Gentleman speaks not. Or had you rather
take a Drink of brown Ale with a Toast, or
March Beer with Sugar and Nutmeg? or had you
rather drink without Sugar?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Good Sir, a Cup of your Household-Beer.
I fear he will draw down to that at last.

div2.stage: Enter Butler with a Silver Can of Sack.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Here, Gentlemen, is a Cup of my Masters
small Beer: But it is good old Canary, I assure you.
And here is to your welcome.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p:
And welcome the Cook says, Gentlemen.
Brother Butler, lay a Napkin, I will fetch a Cut of the
Sirloin to strengthen your patience till my Master
comes, who will not now be long, for he is no Snail,
Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
I have often heard so. And here is to you, Master
Cook -- , Prithee speak, Master Talboy, or force
one Laugh more, if thou canst.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, the Cook drinks to you.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: He is in the same Livory-Beard too.

sp.speaker: Coo.
sp.p:
But he is the oldest Cook, and of the ancientest
House, and the best for House-keeping, in this
County, or the next. And though the Master of it
write but Squire, I know no Lord like him.

And now he is come. Here comes the
Word before him. The Parson has ever the best stomach.
I will Dish away presently.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Is our Master come, Sir Domine?

p.foreign: Est ad Manum. Non est ille testudo.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
He has the Word too in Latin. Now bear up
Talboy.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p:
Give me a Preparative of Sack. It is a gentle
Preparative before Meat. And so a gentle touch of
it to you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
It is a gentle Offer, Sir; and as gently to be
taken.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
About with it, my Lads. And this is as it
should be. -- Not till my turn, Sir, I. Though, I
confess, I have had but three Morning-draughts today.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Yet it appears you were abroad betimes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I am no Snail, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: So your men told us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
But where be my Catchers? Come, a Round.
And so let us drink.

div2.stage:
A Catch sung. And they drink about. The Singers
are all Greybeards.

sp.l: A Round, a Round, a Round, Boys, a Round.
Let Mirth fly aloft, and Sorrow be drowned.
Old Sack, and old Songs, and a Merry old Crew,
Can charm away Cares when the Ground looks blue.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well said old Hearty. And, Gentlemen, welcome.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Ah --

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
O mine ears! What was that, a sigh? And
in my House? Look: has it not split my Walls? If
not, make vent for it: Let it out: I shall be stifled
else.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He hopes your pardon, Sir: his Cause considered.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Cause? Can there be cause for sighing.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He has lost his Mistress. Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Ha ha ha. Is that a Cause? Do you hear me
complain the loss of my two Daughters?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: They are not lost, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
No more can be his Mistress. No woman can
be lost. They may be mislaid a little: but found
again, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Ah --

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Odds my life! He sighs again: And means to
blow me out of my House. To Horse again. Here is
no dwelling for me. Or stay: I will cure him, if I can.
Give him more Sack, to drown his Suspirations.

div2.stage:
While Oldrents and Talboy drink, Oliver takes
Hearty aside.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, I am chiefly to inform you of the Disaster.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: May it concern me?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Your Nephew Martin has stolen my Fathers
Ward, that Gentleman's Bride that should have been.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: It is most true --

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Another Glass of Sack. This Gentleman
brings good news.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Sir, if you can prevent his danger --

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Hang all Preventions. Let them have their
Destiny.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: Sir, I should have had her, it is true --
But she is gone, do ye see? And let her go.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well said. He mends now.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I am glad I am rid of her (do ye see) before I
had more to do with her --

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: He mends apace.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
For should I have married her before she had
run away, do ye see: And that she had run away (do ye see)
after she had been married to me (do ye see.) Then
I had been a married Man without a Wife (do ye see.)
Where now she being run away before I am married
(do ye see) I am no more married to her, do ye see,
than she to me, do ye see. And so long as I am none of
hers (do ye see) nor she none of mine (do ye see) I
ought to care as little for her, now she is run away
(do ye see) as if she had stayed with me, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Why this is excellent! Come hither Hearty.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I perceive it now; and the reason of it; And
how, by Consequence (do ye see) I ought not to look
any further after her.

But that she
should respect a poor base fellow, a Clerk at the
most, and a Serving-man at best, before me, that am
a rich man, at the worst; and a Gentleman, at least,
makes me -- I know not what to say --

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Worse than ever it was! Now he cries out-right.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I know not what to say -- What to say --
O --

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Then I do, Sir. The poor base Fellow, that
you speak of, is my Nephew: As good a Gentleman
as yourself. I understand the business by your
Friend here.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
You shall cry no Mercy, nor anything else
here, Sir; nor for anything here, Sir. This is no
place to cry in: Nor for any business. You, Sir, that
come on business --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: It shall be none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
My House is for no business, but the Belly-business.
You find not me so uncivil, Sir, as to
ask you from whence you came; who you are; or
what is your business. I ask you no question. And
can you be so discourteous, as to tell me, or my
Friend, anything like business. If you come to be
merry with Me, you are welcome. If you have any
business, forget it: You forget where you are else.
And so to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Sir, I pray let me only prevail with you but
to read this.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Spoil my Stomach now, and I will not eat
this fortnight.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
While he reads, let me tell you, Sir. That
my Nephew Martin has stolen that Gentleman's Mistress,
it seems, is true. But I protest, as I am a Gentleman,
I know nothing of the matter; nor where
he or she is. But, as I am the foresaid Gentleman, I
am glad of it with all my heart. Ha, my Boy Mat.
Thou shalt restore our House.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Let him not hear, to grieve him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Grieve him? What should he do with her;
teach their Children to cry?

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
But I do hear you though; and I scorn to cry,
as much as you, do ye see, or your Nephew either,
do ye see.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Now thou art a brave fellow. So, so, hold
up thy head, and thou shalt have a Wife, and a fine
Thing.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Hang a Wife; and Pox on your fine Thing
(do ye see) I scorn your Fopperies, do ye see.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
And I do hear thee, my Boy; and rejoice in
this conversion. If thou canst but hold now.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Yes, I can hold, Sir. And I hold well with
your Sack. I could live and die with it, as I am true
Talboy.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Now thou art a tall Fellow; and shalt want
no Sack.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
And, Sir, I do honour you (do ye see) and
should wish myself one of your Household Servants
(do ye see) if I had but a gray Beard, do ye see? Hay,
as old Master Clack says.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Well, I have read the business here.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Call it not business, I beseech you, Sir.
We defy all business.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Aye marry do we, Sir. Do ye see, Sir? And a
Hay, as old Master Clack says.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Gramercy Sack. Well, I have read the
Matter here written by Master Clack. And do but
bear up in thy humour, I will wait upon thee home.

Hark! they knock to the Dresser. I have heard
much of this old od-ceited Justice Clack: And now
I long to see him. It is but crossing the Country
two days and a nights Journey. We will but dine and
away presently. Bear up, I say, Master Talboy.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
I will bear up, I warrant you, do ye see, Sir --
But here is a grudging still --

div2.stage:
A great noyse within of rude Musick, Laughing,
Singing, &c.
Enter Amie. Rachel. Meriel.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Here is a Wedding with a witness, and a
Holy-day with a hoigh. Let us out of the
noise, as we love our ears.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Yes: and here we may pursue our own Discourse,
and hear one another.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Concerning Springlove and yourself, Mistress
Amie.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Well, Ladies, my confidence in you, that
you are the same that you have protested yourselves
to be, hath so far won upon me, that I confess,
myself well-affected both to the Mind and
Person of that Springlove. And, if he be (as fairly
you pretend) a Gentleman, I shall easily dispense with
Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ra. Me.
sp.p: He is, upon our Honours.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
How well that high Engagement suits your
Habits.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Our Minds and Blood are still the same.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I have past no affiance to the other,
That stole me from my Guardian, and the Match
He would have forced me to: From which I would
Have fled with any, or without a Guide.
Besides, his mind, more clownish than his Habit,
Depraved by Covetousness and Cowardice,
Forced me into a way of misery,
To take relief from Beggars.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: From poor Us.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
And then, to offer to marry me under a
Hedge, as the old couple were today, without
Book or Ring, by the Chaplain of the Beggars Regiment,
your Patrico, only to save Charges.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
I have not seen the Wretch these three hours,
whither is he gone?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
He told me, to fetch Horse and fit Raiment
for us; and so to post me hence: But I think it was
to leave me on your hands.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
He has taken some great distaste sure: For
he is damnable jealous.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Aye, didst thou mark what a wild look he cast,
when Springlove tumbled her, and kissed her on the
Straw this morning, while the Music played to the
old Wedding-Folks?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Yes, and then Springlove, to make him madder,
told him, that he would be his Proxy, and marry
her for him, and lie with her the first night, with
a naked Cudgel betwixt them, and make him a King
of Beggars.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
I saw how it angered him. And I imagined
then, and before, that there was more in Springlove,
than downright Beggar. But though he be never so good
a Gentleman, he shall observe fit time and distance
till we are married.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Matrimony forbid else. (She is taken.) But
while we talk of a Match towards, we are missed within
in the Bride-Barn among the Revel rout.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
We have had all the sport they could make
us, in the past passages.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
How cautious the old contracted Couple
were for Portion and jointure!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
What Feoffs, she being an Heir of fourscore,
(and seven years stone-blind) had, in trust
for her Estate.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
And how carefully he secured all to himself,
in case he out-lived her, being but seven years older
than she. And what pains the Lawyer of the Rout
here, took about it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
And then, how solemnly they were joined,
and admonished, by our Parson Under-hedge, to live
together in the fear of the Lash, and give good example
to the younger Reprobates, to beg within
Compass, to escape the jaws of the Justice, the
Clutch of the Constable, the Hooks of the Headborough,
and the biting blows of the Beadle. And,
in so doing, they should defy the Devil, and all his
Works, and after their painful Pilgrimage in this
life, they should die in the Ditch of Delight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: O but Poet Scribble's Epithalamium.

sp.l: TO the blind Virgin of fourscore,
And the lame Bachelor, of more,
How Cupid gave her Eyes to see,
And Vulcan lent him Legs:
How Venus caused their Sport to be
Prepared with buttered Eggs.
Yet when she shall be seven years wed,
she shall be bold to say,
She has as much her Maiden-head,
As on her Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
So may some Wives that were married at sixteen,
to Lads of one and twenty.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
But at the Wedding-Feast, when the Bride
bridled it, and her Groom saddled it. There was the
sport, in her Mumping, and his Champing; the Crew
scrambling; ourselves trembling; then the confusion
of Noises, in talking, laughing, scolding, singing,
howling; with their Actions, of snatching,
scratching, towsing and lowsing themselves, and one
another --
But who comes here?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
O, Ladies, you have lost as much Mirth, as
would have filled up a week of Holy-days.

div2.stage:
Springlove takes Amie aside, and courts her
in a gentile way.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
I am come about again for the Beggars life
now.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You are. I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: There is no life but it.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: With them there is no Grievance or Perplexity;
No fear of war, or State Disturbances.
No Alteration in a Common-wealth,
Or Innovation, shakes a Thought of theirs.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Of ours you should say.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Of ours, he means.
We have no fear of lessening our Estates;
Nor any grudge with us (without Taxation)
To lend or give, upon command, the whole
Strength of our Wealth for public Benefit:
While some, that are held rich in their Abundance,
(Which is their Misery, indeed) will see
Rather a general ruin upon all,
Than give a Scruple to prevent the Fall.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: It is only we that live.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am glad you are so taken with your Calling.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
We are no less, I assure you. We find the
Sweetness of it now.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
The Mirth, the Pleasure, the Delights. No
Ladies live such Lives.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Some few, upon necessity, perhaps. But that is
not worth gramercy.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: They will never be weary.

sp.speaker: Hil,
sp.p:
Whether we seem to like, or dislike, all is one
to them.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
We must do something to be taken by, and
discovered, we shall never be ourselves, and get
home again else.

div2.stage: Spr. and Amie come to the rest.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I am yours forever. Well, Ladies, you have
missed rare Sport; but now the Bride has missed you
with her half-half eye; and the Bridegroom, with
the help of his Crutches, is drawing her forth for a
Dance, here, in the opener air. The House is now
too hot for them. O, here come the chief Revellers.
The Soldier, the Courtier, the Lawyer, and the Poet,
who is Master of their Revels, before the old Couple
in State. Attend, and hear him speak, as their Inductor.

sp.speaker: Poet.
sp.l: HEre, on this Green, like King and Queen,
(For a short truce) we do produce
Our old new-married Pair.
Of Dish and Wallet, and of Straw-pallet,
With Rags to show, from top to toe,
She is the ancient Heir.
He is the Lord of Bottle-gourd,
Of Satchel great, for Bread and Meat,
And, for small Pence, a Purse.
To all that give, Long may you live
He loudly cries: But who denies
Is sure to have his Curse.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Well said Field-Poet. Phoebus, we see, inspires
As well the Beggar, as the Poet Laureate.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
And shines as warm under a Hedge bottom,
as on the tops of Palaces.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
I have not done yet. Now this is to incite you
to dance.
sp.l: PRepare yourselves, like Fairy Elves,
Now in a Dance to show,
That you approve, the God of Love
Has many Shafts to his Bow:
With Golden head, and some of Lead,
But that which made these feel,
But subtle craft, was sure a Shaft
That headed was with Steel.
For they were old; no Earth more cold;
Their Hearts were Flints entire;
Whence the Steel stroke, did sparks provoke,
That set their Bloods on fire.
Now strike up Piper; and each Lover here
Be blithe, and take his Mistress by the Goll.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That is no Rime, Poet.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
There is as good Poetry in blank Verse, as
Metre.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Come, hay! the Dance, the Dance. Nay
we will have the old Couple in, as blind and lame as they
are.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What will you so?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Well hobbled Bridegroom!

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Well groped Bride!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hay lusty. Hay Holy-day.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Set them down; set them down: They have
done well.

sp.speaker: Gro.
sp.p: Aha! I am lustier than I was thirty years ago.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p:
And I, than I was threescore past. Ahem,
ahem.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: What a night here is towards!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sure they will kill one another.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Each with a fear the tother will live longest.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Poet, thou hast spoken learnedly, and acted
bravely. Thou art both Poet and Actor.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
So has been many famous men. And if here
were no worse, we might have a Masque, or a Comedy
presented tonight, in honour of the old Couple.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Let us each man try his ability
Upon some Subject now extempore.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Agreed. Give us a Theme; and try our Action.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
I have already thought upon it. I want but
Actors.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
What Persons want you? what would you
present?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I would present a Common-wealth; Utopia,
With all her Branches and Consistencies.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I will be Utopia; who must be my Branches?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
The Country, the City, the Court, and the Camp.
Epitomized and personated by a Gentleman, a Merchant,
a Courtier, and a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.p: I will be your Soldier. Am not I one? ha!

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: And am not I a fashionable Courtier?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: But who the Citizen or Merchant?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: And I your Country Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Yet to our Moral I must add two Persons,
Divinity and Law.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why la you now. And am not I a Lawyer?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: But where is Divinity?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Marry that I know not. One of us might do
that, if either knew how to handle it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Where is the old Patrico, our Priest, my
Ghostly Father? He will do it rarely.

sp.speaker: 1 Beg.
sp.p:
He was telling Fortunes even now to Country
Wenches. I will fetch him --

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
That Patrico I wonder at: He has told me
strange things in clouds.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And me somewhat that I may tell you here-after.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: That you shall be my Bride?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I will not tell you now.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Well: but what must our Speeches tend to?
what must we do one with another?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
I would have the Country, the City, and the
Court, be at great variance for Superiority. Then would
I have Divinity and Law stretch their wide throats
to appease and reconcile them: Then would I have
the Soldier cudgel them all together, and overtop
them all. Stay, yet I want another person.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: What must he be?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: A Beggar.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
Here is enough of us, I think. What must
the Beggar do?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
He must, at last, overcome the Soldier; and
bring them all to Beggar-Hall. And this, well acted,
will be for the honour of our Calling.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Scribble! A Scribble!

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
Come, where is this Patrico, that we may
begin?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Alack and welladay, this is no time to play.
Our Quarter is beset. We are all in the Net.
Leave off your merry Glee.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: You begin scurvily.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why what is the Matter?

Bing awast, bing awast. The Quire Love
and the Harmanbeck.

div2.stage: Some Beggars run over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: We are beset indeed. What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: I hope we shall be taken.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
If the good hour be come, welcome by the
grace of good Fortune.

div2.stage:
Enter Sentwell, Constable, Watch. The
Crew slip away.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p:
Beset the Quarter round. Be sure that none
escape.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Lord to come with you, blessed Master, to a many
distressed --

sp.speaker: Vin. Hill.
sp.p: Duly and truly pray for you.

sp.speaker: Ra. Mer.
sp.p: Good your good Worship, duly and truly, etc.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
A many counterfeit Rogues! So frolic and
so lamentable all in a breath? You were acting a
Play but now: We will act with you. Incorrigible Vagabonds.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Good Master, it is a Holy-day with us. An
Heir was married here today.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Married! Not so I hope. Where is she? It is
for an Heir we seek.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Here She is Master -- Hide yourselves in
the Straw -- the Straw. Quickly into the Straw --

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
What tellest thou me of this? And old blind
Beggar-woman. We must find a young gentlewoman-heir
among you. Where is all the rest of the Crew?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
Slipped into the Barn and the Bushes by: but
none can scape.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Look you to that, and to these here.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Into the Straw, I say.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
No, good Springlove. The Ladies and we
are agreed now to draw Stakes, and play this lousy
Game no further.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
We will be taken, and disclose ourselves.
You see we shall be forced to it else. The cowardly
Clerk has done it to save himself.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Do you fear no shame, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Dost think it a shame to leave Begging?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Or that our Father will turn us out to it
again?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Nay, since you are so resolute, Know, that I
myself begin to find this is no course for Gentlemen.
This Lady shall take me off it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Make but your Protestations good, and take
me yours. And for the Gentleman that surprises us,
though he has all my Uncles trust, he shall do anything
for me to our advantage.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p:
If, Springlove, thou couldst post now to thy
Tiring-house, and fetch all our Clothes, we might
get off most neatly.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A Horse and six hours Travel would do that.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: You shall be furnished, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p:
She is scaped, or is invisible. You Sir, I take
to be the chief Rogue of this Regiment. Let him be
whipped till he brings forth the Heir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
That is but till he stinks, Sir. Come, Sir,
strip, strip.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Unhand him, Sir. What Heir do you seek,
Master Sentwell?

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.p:
Precious, how did my haste oversee her? O
Mistress Amie! Could I, or your Uncle, Justice
Clack, a wiser man than I, ever have thought to have
found you in such company?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p:
Of me, Sir, and my company, I have a story
to delight you: which on our March towards your
House, I will relate to you.

sp.speaker: Sent.
sp.l: And thither will I lead you as my Guest.
But to the Law surrender all the rest.
sp.p: I will make your peace.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We must fare all alike.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I have forgiven you. Provided that my Niece
be safely taken; and so to be brought home.
Safely, I say, that is to say, unstained, unblemished,
undishonoured; that is to say, with no more faults,
criminal, or accusative, than those she carried with
her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I believe --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Nay, if we both speak together, how shall
we hear one another? you believe her Virtue is Armour
of proof, without your Counsel or your
Guard; and therefore you left her in the hands of
Rogues and Vagabonds, to make your own Peace
with me. You have it. Provided, I say (as I said
before) that she be safe, that is to say, uncorrupted,
undefiled; that is to say -- as I said before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Mine intent, Sir, and my only way --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Nay, if we both speak together, how shall
we hear one another, as I said before, your intent,
and your only way, you would have said, was to run
away with her; and that by her only Instigation, to
avoid the tie of Marriage with Master Talboy; that
is to say, to shun the Match, that I had made for her;
that is to say, rather to disobey me, than to displease
herself. Wherein (although she did not altogether
transgress the Law) she did both offend and prejudice
me, an Instrument; nay, I may say, a Pillar
thereof. And you, in assisting her, furthering, and
conveying her away, did not only infringe the
Law, in an unlawful Departure from your Master,
but in a higher point; that is to say, Top and top-Gallows
high. I would have found a Jury should have found
it so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But Sir, if it please you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Must we then both speak together? Have I
not born with thee, to speak all thou pleaseth in thy
defence? Have I not broke mine own rule, which
is, to punish before I examine; and so to have the
Law the surer on my side? And dost thou still persist?
HOld your own peace; or, as I am a Justice of the
Kings, I will unsay what I said before, and set a Curat
Lex at you, Sirrah, that shall course you up the
heavy Hill. O, is your Tongue fallen into your Leg
now? Do not you know I have acquitted you? Provided
-- As I said before. Go your way in, and see
that the Gentlemen, who, I think, were got in Sack,
christened in Sack, nursed with Sack, and fed up to
gray hairs with only Sack; see, I say, that they
want no Sack. My Son Oliver (I thank him) has
brought me a pair of such Guests.
O Master Sentwell! Good News?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Of beggarly news, the best you have heard.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
That is to say, you have found my Niece among
the Beggars. That is to say --

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: True, Sir Oliver, I found her --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Now if we both speak together, who shall
hear one another?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: I thought your desire was to be informed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I can inform myself, Sir, by your looks. I
have taken a hundred Examinations in my days of
Felons, and other Offenders, out of their very
Countenances; and wrote them down verbatim, to
what they would have said. I am sure it has served
to hang some of them, and whip the rest.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Justice Clack still! He must talk all. His
Clack must only go.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
But to the point. You have found my Niece.
You have left her at your own House; not only to
shift her out of her Disguise, but out of her shame,
to come nearer me, until I send her pardon.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Most true, Sir. But the Company she was
in --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Again! Do not I know the Company? Beggars,
Rogues, Vagabonds, and Hedge-birds.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
But do you know whom, or how many we
have taken? and how the rest escaped?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
A needless knowledge. Why should we
take more than herself? Or how could you take
those that could escape?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sir, the old Gentlemen within, sent me to
wait upon you. Without you (they say) they need
not my Service.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Tell them then, I will wait on them presently.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
But Sir, we have taken with her such Beggars,
such Rogues, such Vagabonds, and such Hedge-birds
(since you call them so) as you never knew, or
heard of, though now the Countries swarm with
them under every Hedge, as if an innumerable Army
of them were lately disbanded without Pay. Hedge-birds
said you? Hedge Lady-birds, Hedge Cavaliers,
Hedge Soldier, Hedge Lawyer, Hedge Fiddlers, Hedge Poet,
Hedge Players, and a Hedge Priest among them. Such we
have taken for the Principals. But to see how the
Multitude escaped us, was more sport than pity.
How, upon a Watch-word given, they in the instant
vanished by more several ways than there were legs
among them; how the Cripples leaped over Pales
and Hedges; how the Blind found their way through
Lakes and Ditches; how a Doxy flew with two
Children at her back, and two more, perhaps, in her
belly --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A Hedge Priest have you taken, say you?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir, an old Patrico, an ancient Prophet,
to tell Fortunes, and cozen our poor Country People
of their single Money.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Sir, Master Oldrents, in that he enjoys not
your company, begins to doubt of his welcome.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Who led him into that doubt? I, or you that
brought him hither?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Sir, his own desire, and love to you, brought
him hither. I but showed him the way.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You reason fairly. Tell him I come.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be pleased to do so: for he says --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, if we both talk together --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Who shall hear one another.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: But are there Players among the apprehended?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Yes, Sir. And they were contriving to act a
Play among themselves, just as we surprised them, and
spoiled their Sport.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Players! I will pay them above all the rest.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
You shall do well in that; to put them in
stock to set up again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Yes, I will put them in Stocks, and set them up to
the Whipping-post. They can act Justices, can they?
I will act a Justice among them; that is to say, I will
do justice upon them; that is to say --

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Pray Sir, be not severe, they act Kings and
Emperors, as well as Justices. And justice is blind
they say: you may therefore be pleased to wink a
little. I find that you have merry old Gentlemen
in your House, that are come far to visit you. I will
undertake that these Players, with the help of their
Poet; in a device which they have already studied,
and a pack of Clothes which I shall supply them
with, shall give your Guests much content, and
move compassion in you towards the poor Strowles.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
But you know my way of Justice (and that is
a sure way) is to punish them, first, and be compassionate
afterwards, as I find them upon their Examination.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
But for your Guests sake, who (I know) do
favour and affect the Quality of Actors very much,
permit them, Sir. It will enlarge your Entertainment
exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
And perhaps save me the expense of a Renlet
of Sack the while. Well, Sir, for that Respect,
and upon your undertaking that they shall please, I
will prorogue my Justice on the Rogues. And so to
my merry Gentlemen, whom I will prepare to see
their Interlude against after Supper. But pray, Master
Sentwell, as you have found my Niece, look to her,
and see her decently brought home.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
In her own best Apparel. But you must prorogue
your displeasure to her too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
I will do so, until my scarce welcome Guests
be gone.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Sir, my Master sends you word, and plainly,
that without your Company, your Entertainment
stinks. He has commanded me saddle his Nags, and
away tonight. If you come not at once, twice,
thrice, he is gone presently, before Supper; He will
find an Host at an Inn worth a hundred of you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Good friend, I will now satisfy your Master,
without telling him he has a saucy Knave to his
Man.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Thank your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Do you hear, Friend, you serve Master Oldrents.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I could have told you that. And the best
House-keeper my Master is of any Gentleman in the
County he dwells in; and the best Master to a man, as
I, the worst of twenty, can say for him, and would
be ashamed to say less.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Your name is Randall.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Forgive me! Are you so wise? you are too
young to be my Godsire. And I hope not old enough
to be a Witch. How know you, that I am Randall?
were you ever at my Masters House in Nottinghamshire,
or at Dunghilford, where I was born?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: No. But I have Notes to know you by.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
I was never twelve mile from thence in my
life, before this Journey. God send me within ken
of our own Kitchen smoke again.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Your Masters Stewards name is Springlove.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Master Springlove, if it please you. There is
not an honester Gentleman between this and the
head of him. And my heart is with him, wherever
he is. Know you him too?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Yes, and your Masters Daughters too.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
And that they are all from home, your Master
knows not where.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw. Know you that too?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
Yes, and the two young Gentlemen that are
with them, Master Vincent, and Master Hilliard.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Whaw, whaw again. You know them all, I
think. But know you where they all are?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Even here by, at my own House.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw --

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
And they knowing that your Master is here,
and Master Hearty too --

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Whaw, whaw.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p:
And yourself too. They directed me to
find you, Randall, and bring you to them.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Whaw, whaw, whaw, whaw. -- Why do
we not go then?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: But secretly. Not a word to anybody.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Mum -- Will you go then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
O, Master Oldrent's man. Pray let me entreat
you into the Buttery.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Will you go, Master Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Indeed it is my Masters desire, and he commanded
me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Now, when it is Supper-time did he? to fill
my belly with thin drink to save his Meat? It is the
manner in Churls Houses. Will you go, Master Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Introth my Master is so merry with yours
within --

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Shite on your Master. My Master's Steward is
a better Man. I will to him, at this Gentleman's House,
and all the rest. Whaw, whaw.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Randall, you forget.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
Mum again then. Why would you not go
then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
The man is as mad as his Master. The strangest
that ever came to our House.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Well, Martin, for confessing thy fault, and
the means thou madest whereby she is taken, I am
friends with thee. But I shall never look upon her,
or thee -- but with grief of mind, however I bear
it outwardly. O --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You bear it very manfully, methinks.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Aye, you think so, and I know so -- But what
I feel, I feel. Would one of us two had never both
seen one another. -- O --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
You speak very good sense, Sir. But does
my Master continue his merry humour with the old
Gentlemen within.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Yes. Justice Clack's Clack goes as merrily as
any.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Well said, Sir. Now you speak merrily too.
But I could say somewhat that would still him. And
for your comfort, I will tell you. Mistress Amie is fallen
in love with one of the Beggars.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Then have I nothing else to do, but to laugh
at thee as long as I live. Ha ha ha -- To let a Beggar
cozen thee of her. Ha ha ha. A Beggar! I shall die
merrily yet. Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
A hay Boys, a hay. This is right; that is to
say, as I would have it; that is to say --

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: A Beggar. Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
A hay Boys, a hay. They are as merry without,
as we were within. A hay, Master Oldrents, and
Master Hearty! The virtue of your Company turns
all to Mirth and Melody, with a hay trololly lolly lolly.
Is it not so, Master Hearty?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Why thus it should be: How was I deceived!
Now I see you are a good Fellow.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
He was never so before. If it be a Lightning
before Death, the best is, I am his Heir.

sp.speaker: Tal. Mar.
sp.p: Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Again, Boys, again; that is to say, a hay
Boys, ah hay --

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
What is the Motive of your Mirth, Nephew
Martin? Let us laugh with you.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Was that spoke like my Friend, Hearty? Lack
we Motives to laugh? Are not all things, anything,
everything to be laughed at? And if nothing were
to be seen, felt, heard, or understood, we would
laugh at It too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
You take the loss of your Mistress merrily,
Master Talboy.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
More merrily than you will take the finding
of her. Ha ha ha -- A Beggar! Ha ha ha --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Can I be sad to find her, think you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He thinks you will be displeased with her,
and chide her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
You are deceived, Master Talboy; you are
wide, Master Talboy; above half your length, Master
Talboy. Law and Justice shall sleep, and Mirth
and good Fellowship ride a Circuit here tonight. A
hay, Master Oldrents, a hay Master Hearty, and a hay
Son Oliver, and a hay Nephew Talboy,
that should have
been, and a hay, my Clerk Martin, and a hay for
the Players. When come they? Son Oliver, see for
Master Sentwell, that is readier with his new Company.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
Players! Let us go see too. I never saw any
Players.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
This is the first fit that ever he had of this Disease.
And if it be his last, I say as I said before. I
am his Heir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
But is there a Play to be expected, and acted
by Beggars?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
That is to say, by Vagabonds; that is to say,
by strolling Players. They are upon their Purgation.
If they can present anything to please you, they
may escape the Law; that is ( a hay ) If not, tomorrow,
Gentlemen, shall be acted, Abuses stripped and
whipped, among them; with a hay, Master Hearty, you
are not merry.

And a hay
Master Sentwell, where are your Drammatis Personae;
your Prologus, and your Actus Primus, ha? Have they
given you the slip, for fear of the Whip? a hay.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: A word aside, if it please you. --

div1.stage:
Sentwell takes Clack aside, and gives him
a Paper.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I have not known a man in such a Humour.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
And of his own finding! He stole it, indeed,
out of his own Bottles, rather than be robbed of his
Liquor. Misers use to tipple themselves so.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
He does so out-do us, that we look like staid
men again, Hearty; fine sober things.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
But how long will it last? He will hang himself
tomorrow, for the Cost we have put him to.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
I love a Miser's Feast dearly. To see how
thin and scattering the Dishes stood, as if they feared
quarrelling.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
And how the Bottles, to scape breaking one
another, were brought up by one at once!

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
How one of the Serving-men, untrained to
wait, spilt the White-broth!

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
And another, stumbling at the Threshold,
tumbled in his Dish of Rouncevals before him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
And most suitable to the Niggardliness of
his Feast, we shall now have an Entertainment, or
Play, presented by Beggars.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Send them in, Master Sentwell.

Sit Gentlemen, the Players are ready to enter. And
here is a Bill of their Plays. You may take your
choice.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Are they ready for them all in the same
Clothes? Read them, good Hearty.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: First, here is The two lost Daughters.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Put me not in mind of the two lost Daughters,
I prithee. What is the next?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: The vagrant Steward.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Nor of a vagrant Steward. Sure some abuse
is meant me.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: The old Squire and the Fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: That comes nearer me. Away with it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: The Beggars Prophecy.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
All these Titles may serve to one Play, of a
Story that I know too well. I will see none of them.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Then here is The merry Beggars.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Aye, that; and let them begin.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p:
The Players are coming in: And Mistress Amie
and your man Martin, are to be Actors among them.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
A hay then for that too. Some merry device
sure.

Hark! the Beggars
Hoboys. Now they begin.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: See, a most solemn Prologue.

sp.l: To Knight, to Squire, and to the Gentiles here,
We wish our Play may with content appear.
We promise you no dainty Wit of Court,
Nor City Pageantry, nor Country Sport:
But a plain Piece of Action, short and sweet;
In Story true. You will know it when you see it.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
True Stories and true Jests do seldom thrive
On Stages.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
They are best to please you with this though, or
a hay with a Whip for them tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Nay, rather than they shall suffer, I will be
pleased, let them Play their worst.

div1.stage:
A Florish. Enter Patrico. With Lawyer
habited like Oldrents.

sp.p: See our Patrico among them.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: That offered you a Doxy in the Barn.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Your Children's Fortunes I have told,
That they shall Beg ere they be old.
And will you have a Reason why?
It is Justice in their Destiny. --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Justice, ha! Are you meddling with Justices
already?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Your Grandfather, by crafty wile
Of bargaining, did much beguile
A thriftless Heir of half the Lands
That are descended to your hands.
And then, by Law, not Equity,
Forced Him and his Posterity
To Woe and shameful Beggary.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: That was no fault of mine, nor of my Children.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: But our fore-fathers Debts and Crimes,
Although forborne till future times,
Are not so paid. But what needs more,
I wish you happy in your Store.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Dost note this, Hearty?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
You said you would be pleased, let them play
their worst.

div1.stage:
Lawyer walks sadly, beats his breast, &c.
To him enter Souldier like Hearty,
and seems to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
It begins my Story, and by the same Fortune-teller
that told me my Daughters Fortunes; almost
in the same words. I know him now. And he speaks
in the Play to one that personates me, as near, as they
can set him forth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
How like you it, Sir? You seem displeased.
Shall they be whipped yet? A hay, if you say the
word.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: O, by no means, Sir; I am pleased.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Sad for the words of a base Fortune-teller?
Believe him! Hang him. I will trust none of them.
They have all Whims, and double double meanings
In all they say.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: whom does he talk or look like, now?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
It is no matter whom. You are pleased, you
say.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Have you no Sack in the House? am not I here?
And never without a merry old Song?
Old Sack, and old Songs, and a merry old Crew,
Will fright away Cares when the ground looks blue.
And can you think on Gypsy Fortune-tellers?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: I will think as little of them as I can.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Will you abroad then? But here comes your Steward.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Bless me! Is not that Springlove?

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Is that you, that talks to him, or that Coxcomb
I, do you think? Pray let them play their Play:
the Justice will not hinder them, you see; he is asleep.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Here are the Keys of all my Charge, Sir. And
My humble suit is, that you will be pleased
To let me walk upon my known occasions, this Summer.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Fie! Canst not yet leave off those Vagrancies?
But will strive no more to alter Nature.
I will not hinder thee, nor bid thee go.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: My own very words at his departure.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: No matter. Pray attend.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Come, Friend, I will take your Counsel.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: I have striven with myself to alter Nature in me,
For my good Masters sake; but all in vain;
For Beggars, Cuckoo-like, fly out again,
In their own Notes and Season.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Our Father's sadness will not suffer us
To live in his House.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And we must have a Progress.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: The assurance of your Loves hath engaged us

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: To wait on you in any course.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Suppose we will go a-begging.

sp.speaker: Vin. Hil.
sp.l: We are for you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: And that must be your Course, and suddenly,
To cure your Father's sadness; who is told
It is your Destiny: Which you may quit,
By making it a trick of Youth and Wit.
I will set you in the way.

sp.speaker: All 4.
sp.l: But how? But how?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My daughters and their Sweethearts too. I see
The scope of their Design; and the whole drift
Of all their Action now, with joy and comfort.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
But take no notice yet. See a Whim more of it.
But the mad Rogue that acted me, I must make drunk
anon.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Now! are you all resolved?

sp.speaker: All 4.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: You beg to absolve your Fortune, not for need.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
I must commend their Act in that. Prithee
let us call them, and end the matter here. The purpose
of their Play, is but to work my Friendship, or their
Peace with me; and they have it.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: But see a little more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
My Man Randall too! Has he a Part with
them?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
They were well set a-work, when they
made me a Player. What is that I must say? And
how must I act now? O! that I must be Steward
for the Beggars in Master Steward's absence; and tell
my Master, he is gone to measure Land for him to
purchase.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
You Sir. Leave the work you can do no better
(I can forbear no longer) and call the Actors
back again to me.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p:
With all my heart. And glad my Part is so
soon done.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Since you will then break off our Play:
Something in earnest I must say;
But let affected Riming go.
I will be no more a Patrico.
My name is Wrought-on -- Start not. But (if you
Desire to hear what is worth your best attention,
More privately) you may draw nearer me.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Hear no more Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: You shall give me leave.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: I am Grandson to that unhappy Wrought-on,
Whom your Grandfather, craftily, wrought out
Of his Estate. By which, all his Posterity
Were, since, exposed to Beggary. I do not charge
You, with the least offence in this. But, now,
Come nearer me: for I must whisper to you.
I had a Sister, who among the Race
Of Beggars, was the fairest. Fair she was
In Gentle Blood, and Gesture to her Beauty;
Which could not be so clouded with base Clothing,
But she attracted Love from worthy Persons;
Which (for her meanness) they expressed in Pity,
For the most part. But some assaulted her
With amorous, though loose desires; which she
Had virtue to withstand. only one Gentleman
(Whether it were by her Affection, or
His Fate, to send his Blood a-begging with her,
I question not) by her, in heat of Youth,
Did get a Son, who now must call you Father.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You. Attend me, Sir. Your Bounty, then,
Disposed your Purse to her; In which, besides
Much Money (I conceive by your neglect)
Was thrown this holy Relic. Do you know it?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: The Agnus Dei that my Mother gave me
Upon her Death-bed! O the loss of it
Was my sore grief: And, now, with joy, it is
Restored by Miracle! Does your Sister live?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: No, Sir. She died within a few days after
Her Son was born; and left him to my care;
On whom, I, to this day, have had an eye,
In all his wanderings.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Then the young Man lives!

div1.stage:
Enter Springlove. Vincent. Hilliard. Rachell.
Meriel.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Here with the rest of your fair Children, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: My Joy begins to be too great within me!
My Blessing, and a Welcome to you all.
Be one another's, and you all are mine.

sp.speaker: Vin. Hil.
sp.l: We are agreed on that.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Long since. We only stood till you shook
off your Sadness.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: For which we were fain to go a-begging, Sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Now I can read the Justice of my Fate, and
yours --

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha! Justice? Are they handling of Justice?

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: But more applaud great Providence in both.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Are they jeering of Justices? I watched for
that.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p: Aye so methought. No, Sir. The Play is done.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: See, Sir, your Niece presented to you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
What, with a speech by one of the Players?
Speak, Sir: and be not daunted. I am favourable.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
Then, by your favour, Sir, this Maiden is my
Wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Sure you are out of your part. That is to say,
you must begin again.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: She is mine by solemn Contract, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
You will not tell me that. Are not you my
Niece?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: I dare not, Sir, deny it, we are contracted.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Nay, if we both speak together, how shall
we hear one another?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I must disprove the Contract.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: That is my part to speak.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: None can disprove it. I am witness to it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nay, if we all speak -- as I said before.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Hear me for all then. Here are no Beggars
(you are but one, Patrico ) no Rogues, nor Players: But
a select Company, to fill this House with Mirth.
These are my Daughters; these their Husbands; and
this that shall marry your Niece, a Gentleman, my
Son. I will instantly Estate him in a thousand pound
a year to entertain his Wife; and to their Heirs forever.
Do you hear me now?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Now I do hear you. And I must hear you.
That is to say, it is a Match. That is to say -- as I
said before.

sp.speaker: Tal.
sp.p: And must I hear it too -- O --

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Yes, though you whine your eyes out.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.p:
Nephew Martin, still the Child with a Suck-bottle
of Sack. Peace, lamb; and I will find a wife
for thee.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Now, Patrico, if you can quit your Function,
To live a moderate Gentleman, I will give you
A competent Annuity for your life.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: I will be, withal, your faithful Beads-man; and
Spend my whole life in Prayers for you and yours.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
And now, Clerk Martin, give all the Beggars
my free Pass, without all manner of Correction?
that is to say, with a hay get them gone.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p:
Are not you the Gentleman, that challenged
me in right of your Friend here?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Your Inspection is good, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
And you the Gentleman (I take it) that would
have made Beggar-sport with us, two at once.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: For twelve pence a-piece, Sir.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I hope we all are Friends.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Now, on my Duty, Sir, I will beg no more,
But your continual Love, and daily blessing.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p:
Except it be at Court, Boy; where if ever I
come, it shall be to beg the next Fool-Royal's place
that falls.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: A begging Epilogue yet would not be,
Methinks, improper to this Comedy.
Though we are, now, no Beggars of the Crew,
We count it not a shame to beg of you.
The Justice, here, has given his Pass free
To all the rest, unpunished; only we
Are under Censure, till we do obtain
Your Suffrages, that we may beg again;
And often, in the Course, We took today,
Which was intended, for your Mirth, a Play;
Not without Action, and a little Wit,
Therefore we beg your Pass for us and It.
